BUTTERFLIES Falsify Evolution:
1- The butterfly has two distinctly different body plans
2- Only the second one has the means of fertilisation and reproduction
3- Evolution assumes it evolved from a creature with one body plan and its own means of fertilisation and reproduction
4- The second body plan cannot function until it is complete in both a male and a female simultaneously
5- So complimentary second body plans must evolve in male and female without the aid of natural selection over generations
6- Evolution cannot by definition work without the benefit of natural selection contradicting the basis of the theory
7- It is also fanciful to imagine the random process could time the moment of transfer of the complex reproductive mechanism from the first to the second body plan in both a male and female to coincide exactly at the moment of their completion!
8- "We can often learn about evolution from the fossil record, but there are relatively few butterfly fossils. Those that do exist, like the 40-million-year-old Prodryas persophone, are remarkably similar to modern-day forms—so the fossil record sheds little light on the origin of today's butterflies." American Museum of Natural History
Evolution by Natural Selection is falsified by contradiction of its most basic premise! Q.E.D.

The DNA problem:
1) DNA is the carrier molecule for the transmission and inheritance of information in all living creatures
2) Long chain molecules of DNA carry the specifications of the structure, systems and processes of life
3) An essential battery of proteins and enzymes are required to store, read and reproduce DNA
4) All proteins and enzymes are specified in DNA and are made by the reading and transcrption of DNA
5) DNA alone has no function until it can be read and transcribed by the very molecules it specifies
6) The proteins and enzymes that store, read and reproduce DNA have no function without DNA
7) Hence DNA and the molecules that store, read and reproduce it are mutually dependant!
Evolution of DNA by natural selection is falsified by the contradiction it alone is not selectable! Q.E.D

If living things and dead things are exectly the same, surely the laws of observation of quantum mechanics are wrong. If only living things, or things built by them, can observe particles thereby effecting them... There must be some fundamental difference between living things and dead things. I personally believe the laws of quantum mechanics are wrong, like everything we are bias.

The same bias that caused us to see the earth as the centre of the universe could be behind it. There's probably a more complex reason behind observation laws and our nature as humans is to assume we are effecting the particles. If life was never a guarantee, why would there be laws of the universe only affected by living organisms?

I think the intrigue of the concept also hinders us. From what we've seen, just observing the universe changes it. That means you always have some effect, however slight, on the huge world around you. That idea is comforting, I'm not sure if it's realistic though. The idea of entire regions of space locked in superposition, waiting to be observed like map chunks being loaded from game memory... Its a fascinating idea, a brilliant sci-fi concept, and utterly proposterous when analysing it.

Have you ever lied, stolen the smallest thing or thought a rude thought? If these were the things God would judge us by, would He find us innocent or guilty? The answer? Guilty. Sinning against an infinite authority figure brings infinite punishment. Hell.

So how can we stop going to hell? Does doing good deeds take away our sins? If I get a speeding ticket in the morning, then do 5 good things, should the judge let me go free? No, the fine has to be paid.

"[A cell] is a protein-based robot."
Or maybe robots are mineral-based organisms.
This is a woefully bad description for a video trying to draw the distinction between life and death, but it does reveal our unspoken assumptions about life that are likely impeding our understanding.
Saying that no part of a cell is alive is as absurd as saying no part of the human nervous system is intelligent; if that isn't intelligent, what the hell is? It's an excessively reductionist way of thinking about it. It's like cutting apart a TV remote to see what's inside and expecting the individual fragments to carry on the functions the remote performs as a whole. Or expecting one stroke of a pen in isolation to carry the same meaning as a finished drawing. At the very least, it can be said that life is more than the sum of it's parts.

What's really trying to be said is, I think, that for something that represents the inner workings of human tissue, there doesn't seem to be anything to distinguish these living systems from organic compounds that are distinctly not alive.
There is the tacit assumption that something about hydrocarbon molecules has to change in the process of being incorporated into a cell for it to be considered alive, but since they don't suddenly become magic sentient hydrocarbons they're actually still as dead as the digested hamburger they came from, or the petroleum in the ground. Again, not a good assumption for a video trying to define life. It could just as easily be suggested that, rather than the human body being more dead and mechanistic than we normally think about it, non-living substances have more the character of life than we normally suppose.

[The goal of life is to reproduce itself so life can keep going.]
Is it? Is it the goal of a wave on the ocean to make other waves? Or does it just happen? If you're going to say that both are distortions in the quantum fields of the universe, then both might as well have the same intentionality behind them. Reproduction is certainly something that a rabbit is compelled to do, but it never makes any plans. It just does it. Like a ball rolling down a hill under the effects of gravity. Again, I propose we look at this comparison both ways: the rabbit could be thought of as being as much a blind motion of energy as the ball, or the ball could be seen as a living process just like the rabbit.
Science is resistant to the idea that objects dubbed inanimate have anything resembling living qualities because this has connotations of irrationality and superstition, but there isn't actually any rational basis to support this. It is a dogma that scientists never question with uncharacteristic ignorance and bias.

"Mitochondria are not alive anymore."
Who says? This is purely arbitrary. The video assumes DNA is dead because it can't do anything on it's own, but when given an organelle that can do something independent of it's host cell, it's discarded. Even then, Abiogenesis assumes DNA arose before the rest of the cell structure. So what has to be added to the mix of molecules before it gets to be considered alive? There is no way of deciding except arbitrarily so the distinction between living and dead is a ruse.
Where does your torso end and your arm begin? One is very clearly distinct from the other, but the transition between the two is completely seamless. From one perspective, it makes sense to define the arm as starting with the humerus or the scapula, but in terms of the arm's function and motion, it makes more sense to think of the arm as starting at the pit of the neck where the clavicle meets the sternum. Neither is more valid than the other, so it's arbitrary. The arm is an outgrowth of the torso and the torso is the root of the arm, but the two are not separate things. They are an interdependent whole.

"Is the universe dead or alive?"
Is the arm a part of the torso or is the torso a part of the arm? The torso seems larger and houses vital organs that the arms need to exist, but these organs can't function of the human body is unable to feed itself and survive. The areas for motor control in the cortex devoted to the hands completely dwarfs that used for any other part of the body, which alone should express how vital this supposedly non-vital limb really is to the organism as a whole.
All we can say is that if there is a distinction between life and death, the two are conjoined rather than separate.
But I would add that I think our perspectives are skewed towards thinking that if this distinction breaks down, the living parts fell less alive rather than the dead parts feeling less dead, and I don't think this is valid. It would be easier for us to feel gratitude to look at it the other way around:

This universe is not dead. There are relatively concentrated areas of life, like our planet, and areas of less life, but our conceptual boundaries for what is alive do not have any definable limit. It extends right across the observable universe like a gravitational field that gets weaker with distance but never actually vanishes.

A bacteriophage may protect itself and its host against a deadly effect of bright sunlight.
Cyanobacteria...are susceptible to...photo-inhibition when sunlight is too intense. Here we show that the genomic sequence of one such virus, a bacteriophage known as S-PM2, encodes the D1 and D2 proteins that are key components of one of the photo-synthetic reaction centres (photosystem II, PSII), which are crucial sites of damage in photo-inhibition...The expression of virus-encoded D1 and D2 proteins in infected cells would allow a repair cycle to operate in PSII after the host’s protein synthesis had been shut down, thereby maintaining the cells’ photosynthetic activity
The idea being, a cell may be dying/‘newly dead’ due to sunlight damage, but when the virus infects it, it replaces the dying part and the cell remains alive. So it would have been better portrayed in kurgesagt if the cell way dying and was then revived by the virus.
In other words the CLAIM that a virus can bring a dead cell back to life is not substantiated or proven. I've found this "scientific" channel to be engaging in beliefs or epistemological conditions that are seriously flawed a tad too often to take it seriously.

If one is open-minded to the possibility of reality being “idealistic” (mind-based) in nature, then literally everything throughout the universe is alive. And that includes the fusion cores of the stars, right down to the keyboard I am using to type this comment.

Now I don’t mean that these material phenomena are “conscious” in any way, but just imbued with the essence of life itself.

The point is that from the perspective of idealism, the video is wrong when it stated the following:

“...of all the stuff that makes up a cell, no part is alive...”

Now the ultimate point is that if the fabric of reality is already saturated with the essence of life, then it is simply a tiny little step in accepting how “inanimate” (yet living) matter could become “animate” matter in the form of evolvable microorganisms.

Hence the “emergence” of that implicit life through the process that we call “abiogenesis” – an emergence that eventually evolves into self-aware levels of consciousness like that of humans.

Lessons I’ve learned in life:
🌟We spend most of our time and a great deal of our emotional energy living in time that is not here, in an elsewhere which is not concretely real. So we develop a chronic anxiety about time and forget to realise that reality can only be found in the present moment. The future is a concept it doesn’t exist- there is only an eternal now

🌟Life is a pattern, a dance of energy
What makes an energy system is the concept that it let’s go of itself

🌟I evoke light out of stars, hardness out of wood- my ear drums evoke sound out of vibrations in the air
I am the universe experiencing itself

🌟Experience polarises itself as self and other just as a magnet has a south and North Pole - but it’s one
You wouldn’t know the meaning of happiness without sadness, good without evil.. you can’t have a front without a back, a penny with two heads, black without white.
All things which have a beginning must have an end.

🌟True love is a love of giving not of receiving - you surrender yourself although there’s a high chance it won’t work out. And if it doesn’t that’s okay. It’s about the journey not the outcome.

🌟In madness lies sanity - what is conflict at one level is harmony at another

🌟The subprime self is absorbed in all the different pathways and organisms which constitute life, it’s so invested it forgets its playing a game
All this world is a big act- at the end we’ll sit back and say well wasn’t that a great show

🌟Meditation is the discovery that the point of life is always arrived at in the immediate moment

🌟There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than the image of our world as a speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. This only underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another and to cherish and preserve this small blue dot- the only home we have ever known.

🌟Do it all. Make art, learn science, fall in love, contemplate existence.. challenge yourself. Do everything you can. Experience everything while you can.

🌟Drift like a cloud, flow like water seeing that all life is a magnificent allusion, a playing of energy and there is nothing fundamentally to be afraid of

I've got a potential new definition for life and living brings; as we all know, a living brings require energy to perform basic functions, and this energy comes from external sources. Perhaps we should be trying to base what life is upon the very bare level of what makes all living creatures "alive" to begin with; the 'urge' to perform a task. I was originally thought that this wouldn't apply to all forms of life, specifically plants however plants also need to perform duties to keep themselves alive..

Let's summarize this:

All living things have an 'urge' or desire to perform a task.

Personally I feel that the status of life shouldn't be based upon an organism at mass, for instance a human, snake, tree, or flower, but rather the smallest component of that bigger organism as a whole, so to my understanding, cells. Cells fit this description quite easily, they have the urge to seek out nutrients to survive. I feel the idea that we as massive organisms are something different than what we are composed of is quite 1 directional, why must be base the world around our own view and understanding of it; and does there really need to be a long and drawn out explanation and description for everything? Can't some things just be put simply and be done?

While the definition I present to you tonight is quite brief, and doesn't go too much into details, there is certainly one aspect that people planning for the future can truly get behind, this definition doesn't leave out potential AI or AI Machines from being included as "living" beings. An AI machine can have an urge to perform a task, and if you ask me, that is enough to argue life. Even if an entity doesn't or is incapable of arguing its status of living does not mean that it isn't alive or that it cannot 'live', a perfect example would be a newborn infant since we were all infants once, and when we were infants we couldn't speak, let alone argue that we were living; does this mean we weren't then and aren't now living, no however it is a great place to start since it requires people to comprehend that the world is not everything that we perceive it to be, and like can REALLY by deceiving.

There is no God but He, everything will perish save His countenance, His is the command and to Him shall you return. {[*]: Qur'an, 28:88.}
Death is a proof of dominicality as much as life is a proof of it; it is a most powerful proof of Divine unity. As the verse,
Who creates death and life {[*]: Qur'an, 67:2.}
indicates, death is not non-existence, annihilation, non-being, an authorless extinction; rather, as is shown in the First Letter, it is a being discharged from service by an All-Wise Author, a change of residence, an exchange of bodies, a rest from duty, a being freed from the prison of the body; it is a wise and orderly work of wisdom. Indeed, just as the living face of the earth and the well-fashioned and living creatures upon it testify to the necessary existence and unity of an All-Wise Maker, so too with their deaths do those living beings bear witness to the eternity and unity of an Ever-Living and Self-Subsistent One. Since it is proved and elucidated in the Twenty-Second Word that death is an extremely powerful proof of Divine unity and eternity, we refer the discussion to that Word and here only explain one important point. It is as follows:
Both with their existences do living beings point to the existence of a Necessarily Existent One, and with their deaths do those living beings testify to the eternity and unity of an Ever-Living Eternal One. For example, the face of the earth, which is a single living creature, points to its Maker with its order and circumstances; so too it points to Him when it dies. That is, when winter conceals the earth's face with its white shroud, it turns the gazes of men away from itself their gaze moves to the past behind the corpse of that departing spring and it shows them a far wider scene. That is to say, all the past springs of the earth, which were all miracles of power, inform them that new living springtime creatures of the earth will come, and since they all testify to the existence of those future wonders of Divine power, each a living earth, they testify brilliantly and powerfully and on a vast scale to the necessary existence, unity, everlastingness, and eternity of an All-Glorious Maker, an All-Powerful One of Perfection, an Ever-Living Eternal One; they demonstrate such brilliant proofs that whether one wants to or not they make one declare: "I believe in God, the One, the Unique!" In Short: According to the meaning of the verse,
And gives life to the earth after its death, {[*]: Qur'an, 30:19.}
just as this living earth testifies to the Maker with the spring, so with its death it turns man's gaze to the miracles of Divine power lined up on the two wings of time, the past and the future; it alludes to thousands of miracles of power in place of one miracle. And each of those springs testifies more certainly than this present spring, for those which have departed towards the past have gone together with their apparent causes, and after them others like them have come in their places. This means that apparent causes are nothing: only that an All-Powerful One of Glory creates the springs, and tying them to causes shows that He has sent them. As for the faces of the earth lined up in future time, they testify still more brilliantly. For they will be made anew from nothing, from non-being, and sent; they will be put on the earth, made to do their duty, and then sent away.
And so, O heedless one deviated into nature and drowning in its swamp! How can something which does not possess hands wise and powerful enough to reach all the past and all the future interfere in the life of the earth? Can your total nonentity of nature interfere in it? If you want to be saved, say: "At the very most, nature is a notebook of Divine power. And as for chance, it is a veil to hidden Divine wisdom which conceals our ignorance." Approach the truth!

Who creates death and life. {[*]: Qur'an, 67:2.}
Life is the most luminous, the most beautiful of the miracles of dominical power. It is the most powerful and most brilliant of the proofs of Divine unity. It is the most comprehensive and most shining of the mirrors displaying the manifestations of the Eternally Besought One. Yes, on its own, life makes known a Living and Self-Subsistent One together with all his Names and acts. For life is a light, a medicament, like a potion blended from numerous attributes. Just as the seven colours are combined in light, and various drugs are blended together in a medicament, so life is a reality made of numerous attributes. Some of the attributes in its reality expand by means of the senses; they unfold and are differentiated. However the greater part make themselves perceived in the form of the emotions; they make themselves known by welling up out of life.
Furthermore, life comprises sustenance, mercy, grace, and wisdom, which are dominant in the planning and administration of the universe. It is as if life fastens them on behind it and draws them into the place it enters. For example, when life enters a body, the Name of All-Wise is also manifested; it makes its home well and orders it with wisdom. In the same way, the Name of All-Generous is manifested, and it organizes and decorates its dwelling according to its needs. At the same time, the manifestation of the Name of All-Compassionate is apparent; it bestows all sorts of bounties for the continuance and perfection of life. Again at the same time, the manifestation of the Name of Provider appears; it produces the sustenance, material and immaterial, necessary for the perpetuation and unfolding of the life, and in part stores them up within its body. That is to say, life is like a point of focus; various attributes enter one another, indeed, they become one and the same. It is as if in its entirety life is both knowledge, and at the same time power, and at the same time wisdom and mercy, and so on... Thus, with regard to this comprehensive essence, life is a mirror of the Eternally Besought One reflecting the essential dominical attributes. It is due to this mystery that the Necessarily Existent One, Who is the Ever-Living and Self-Subsistent One, creates life in great abundance and plenitude, and scatters it far and wide and broadcasts it, and gathers everything around life and makes it serve it. For life's duty is great. Yes, it is not easy to be the mirror of the Eternally Besought One, it is not some petty duty.
Thus, the instantaneous and continuous coming into existence from nothing of these countless, numberless lives which we all the time see before our eyes, and of spirits, which are the origins and essences of lives their being sent, demonstrate the necessary existence, sacred attributes, and Most Beautiful Names of a Necessarily Existent and Ever-Living and Self-Subsistent One as clearly as sunbeams show the existence of the sun. Just as someone who does not recognize and accept the existence of the sun is compelled to deny the light which fills the day, so one who does not recognize the Sun of Divine Oneness, Who is Ever-Living and Self-Subsistent and the Giver of Life and Death, has to deny the existence of the living creatures which fill the earth and even the past and the future; he has to fall a hundred times lower than an animal, to fall from the level of life to become something utterly ignorant and lifeless.

Here is my humble attempt at answering the question- is anything alive or dead? Since everything is made up of atoms and they have electrons which spin around the nucleus, a force makes them spin. So, basically, it’s ‘alive’. When someone ‘dies’, the electrons in atoms that made up that person do not stop spinning. So, death is really a change of state for the atoms and molecules that made that person. Nothing ever dies. It’s an illusion like time and space. It’s like saying I took a glass of water from the ocean, so a new ‘glass of water’ is born and when I poured it back in the ocean, it can’t be identified again since it was just water, always. So by me pouring it back in ocean, did the ‘glass of water’ “die”? No, since It was never born. No birth and no death.

In my understanding life is somewhat like the centrifugal force. We can observe its effects, it's intuitive to us, but in the end, it is a fictitious force. Nothing but an interpretation of an orchestra of effects under the hood, something we like to give a name because it is so dear and normal to us, but in reality it is just different to our initial expectations.
This also explains exactly why we are unsure of where to put viruses, they are not a lifeform in a simple standard way we see every day though at the same time they have similarities to what "clearly" is life.

In the end, it is my opinion that the very bottom-line in science should not describe life as a real phenomenon. Instead, life is loose description of many chemical reactions that by chance found together and were and are able to support themselves in a way that allows seemingly complex behavior, even intelligence in the end! But the latter is a whole new topic - though in short I think of it just as I described I do of life.

Looking too deep into something existential is pointless, life should have a simple, clear definition.

The only key to a peaceful world is love. It is realizing we are all human and accepting each other for who we are. Everything in this world is connected. For example the high unemployment rate directly connects to the suicide rate. Untreated mental, psychological, or social emotional issues connects to the gun violence and homicide rate. You think about gangs and gang violence and there all in the poorest most forgotten communites in the country. When you say something mean to someone they take that bitterness with them and spill it on to others. Most of society today are confused on how to approach this thing called life. Some people believe in diffrent gods others believe in science and some people believe in nothing and this is place where we all are divided and begin to clash but the truth is right in front of us we are letting our beliefs and opinions that weve learned tear us all apart coupled with things like race, politics , age , financial status, and region of the country we are constantly being divided. Which is making a stable society further from our grasp. It is amazing to me how we are in the age of the internet, and space stations but we still havent figured out a peaceful way to live amongst ourselfs. You see in a perfect world people are supported, loved , and given a sense of belonging. But it cant just be the lucky few it has to be worldwide. If we can somehow across continent to continent realize we are all the same and treating eachother as brother and sister instead of a bunch strangers then we would be on the correct path. Also financial stability can you imagine where the human race would be if it wasnt just a few major countries with space flight capabilties but the entire continent of africa and south america had the same advancement in technology as the usa did today? People who normally would have been refugees, victims of poverty , people who would have been busy searching for a clean water source would know be invested in something to help change the world and bringing in new ideas and concepts to the world. It really isnt radical to believe its possible if we could all just love and help one another and combine all of our might this world would be immaculate.

Contrary to popular belief, Darwin never disproved that humans have unique properties, not did he make any philosophically relevant observation that hadn't already been stated by Epicurus. The "magic" that sets humans (and some animals) apart from other things in the universe is that we have goals that we are capable of reflecting on. This is something a computer will never be able to replicate because it is only a set of premises chosen by its programmer, it does not recognize final goals, but only processes (see the halting problem). On the other hand, if human consciousness were explainable by an advanced form of natural instinct, then what we call "science" would only be reading in personal or cultural biases into a series of events, and not an impersonal discovery.

Hey, if you (or anyone!) is reading this, I just want to say something.

I have a purpose. I know what the point of life is. I know that there is a reason for everyone being born at the time they were, the weight they were, and are now, it's all part of one big plan. The Big Plan.

God's plan. He has a purpose for me. How do I know? The Bible tells me!

We know that in all things God works for good with those who love him, those whom he has called according to his purpose. (Romans 8:28)

All things are done according to God’s plan and decision; and God chose us to be his own people in union with Christ because of his own purpose, based on what he had decided from the very beginning. (Ephesians 1:11)

You were chosen according to the purpose of God the Father and were made a holy people by his Spirit, to obey Jesus Christ and be purified by his blood. May grace and peace be yours in full measure. (1 Peter 1:2)


So, in short, God has a purpose for me, and everyone.

God is eternal. He is all powerful, all loving, and omnipresent. He created space, time, gravity, and exists outside those barriers.

The world was perfect. God put Adam and Eve onto this Earth. They were perfect. Then, because of Satan, they sinned.
They brought sin into the world forever. The only way to heaven is to be perfect.

So no one gets to Heaven, right?

BUT!

God loved us so so SO much that he sent Jesus down, His Son, God in human form down to earth, to live the perfect life, die for our sins and take our punishment, and rise 3 days later. Isn't that cool?

I follow God because I've seen what he's done for me. How he's changed me. Not to mention, the Bible has geological proof, and it all lines up. It's crazy!

One day soon, Jesus will come back down, and there will be a judgment day. Everyone will be judged not by their deeds, but by their Faith in God.



Christianity isn't just a religion. It's a relationship with God. Here on Earth, and in Heaven.

Life is not a particle. There's no organ or organelle inside a cell which tells you 'This thing is alive'.
Life is a pattern.
Life is not a material thing but rather it is the collective order of material things. Patterns which repeat and duplicate over time. Disordered life dies, and is dissolved via entropy, while ordered life survives and feeds off entropy to increase order.
Life can only exist while imbalance exists. Perfect balance is maximum entropy, and thus no energy can be harvested to sustain life.

I think the answer is very simple. I don't even think the ability to reproduce is a requirement of life. Since if someone becomes/is infertile they aren't suddenly considered dead. I think the real situation is that anything which is capable of recieving information and then processing this input is considered alive. Thus almost everything in the known universe is considered somewhat alive. For example a rock can receive informational nput in the form of heat and can process this information by increasing the energy in its own molecules resulting in a change of physical state. Since everything is alive from a rock to a plant to an insect to an animal to a human. The next question is how do we differentiate these different forms of life. The answer is by how intelligent the life is. To define the degree of intelligent life there is you must consider the quantities and qualities of informational input that can be received and processed. This explains why we value human life over animal life, animal life over insect life, insect life over plant life and plant life over rock life. This is why if somebody was in a horrible accident and suffers what's known as locked in syndrome we consider then just as alive as anybody else however if someone suffers a horrible accident and is in a coma for ever then we don't.

What makes something alive not determined by what it is or what information it carries, rather it is by the processes it performs. We define something as alive if it: maintains separation from external environment, maintains internal conditions (such as temperature and solute concentration), grows/develops, transduces and reacts to signals from the environment, reproduces sexually or asexually passing on its genetic information, and extracts and uses energy (from food, light, etc.) to carry out all of these processes. If it is not doing all these things it’s dead, even though it may be doing some of them.

Here is how you determine if something is living or not. I learned this in my Biology class, basically it's what all organisms/living things have in common which means they are alive. H.A.R.D.C.O.R.E, Homeostasis, Adaption, Reproduction, Development, Change, Organization, Response, Evolution. If the "thing" misses one of these things it's not living. For an example, viruses are not living things even though it matches Hardcore, except for one of the R's for reproduction. Viruses need a host to reproduce, they can't do it sexually or asexually. I find this method very useful.

You have already told that we and the stars share the same elements but yet we are different. Now consider a copper wire and some silicon chips. In its raw state it is useless, but if we form resistors, transistors and capacitors with it we can use it to make logic gates which are used to make computers. Yet they show a blank screen unless a driving force is given to it, which in this case is electricity. Also the electricity is given in form of specific input to get the desired output. After doing so a computer can evolve and generate feelings, thoughts and do many other things (Now-a-days we can even see such kind of self-aware computers). Humans are no different than computers who have also evolved a lot from nothing to many thing. But how did our 'dead' body of logic gates gained life? Well, similar to that of computers, there might have been a electric or any other force
(I mostly believe that it might have been pure energy which some refer to as soul) was provided to 1st living-dead cell under specific conditions to get the desired output of being alive. Over the life the force or energy remains in our body and acts as our subconscious mind. We use small fractions of this energy throughout our live for everything we do, hear, speak, see, feel, etc (We may not even use it as it may be infinite source of energy). At the time of death, I have some predictions about what happens to the energy-
1. If the source of energy is finite
1. The energy might get completely used up (like battery of a phone or laptop).
2. Or the energy may get converted into some mass (if there is any energy remaining in the being).
3. Or the energy may get converted into any other form of energy we may not know of.
2. If the source of energy is infinite
1. Or the energy may just exit out of body and become omnipresent, that is, it may spread all over the universe
2. Or the energy might exit out of body but instead of becoming omnipresent, it may act as driving force for another 'dead' body to gain life and thus forming a eternal cycle of rebirth.

Speaking of this theory, either of it may be true or it may be completely wrong. By Schroedinger's definition, a rock is alive because it weathers the elements and maintains its form, for a certain period of time. Holding patterns are everywhere, not just in fleshy things. Crystals have matrices that reproduce, for instance. A conflagration sustains a reaction with a specific cycle of growth, by feeding upon a fuel source. Even the roots of trees are in part 'xylem', something percieved dead, grown from the living, which nevertheless supports a tree's nutrient intake pattern. And humans grow this stuff called 'hair', nails, and so forth, which is not living by conventional definitions, but which nevertheless sustains a certain pattern, and aids us in tasks like picking up objects, picking off parasitic organisms, helps us regulate body temperature, etc.

In short, life is simply an arbitrary degree of complexity we have chosen as our frame of reference for study.

"life" is an arbitrary line drawn by language, I'm amused that this was touched upon but not noticed in the video. Kind of how something being "stupid" means nothing until we define what stupid means. What annoys me however, is when the line of what is "life" is blurred so far that scientifically minded people can't help but define it as nothing at all.

When you line up two possibilities, one being we're "magic", and the other being that we're no more significant than a rock, then I feel cheated out of a good question. Nobody has ruled out "magic", after all, we merely thought that it's possible that we're all meat robots, and then everyone suddenly started thinking that the magic idea was absurd. But what is magic, anyway? And why is it laughed out without ever being successfully defined or debunked? Because a few proposed ideas of it are stupid? Well naturally, they would be! Because there's no answering this question yet, we don't know where or how to look for the answer. So it just frustrates me that everyone thinks they know the answer, when all they're really doing is changing the definitions of words, until nobody is even talking the same language anymore.

I believe I have found the answer. When an organism is alive there is a certain set of reactions and activities that take place in that organism in one unit time, which is specific to that organism and relates to the species of that organism. When an organism is dead there is also a certain set of chemical reactions taking place within the organism (decomposition), even though the organism is dead. So by looking at it critically you can summarize...

When an organism is alive there is a certain set of chemical reactions going on inside of it, and death is simply when the organism’s cells decide that the best way to further the ‘lifespan’ of the genetic material they hold is for there to be such a drastic shift in the type of reactions and goals of the reactions that the organism, in purpose, becomes something completely different than what it was when it was alive.
The only difference between life and death is the type of reactions that take place and the goals of those reactions.

What is life? Is Death Real? Ask a physicist. We are electric/magnetic energy fields existing in a unified field of electric/magnetic energy fields. Barbara Brennan, a former NASA physicist, now healer, says we are eternal, holographic, multidimensional, electromagnetic energy/light beings. Read her book: "Hands of Light".

I receive email from the site "Ask a Mathematician, Ask a Physicist". Here is the latest I received:

Q: What are "actual pictures" of atoms actually pictures of?.

Physicist: Actual pictures of atoms aren’t actually pictures at all. There are a few good rules of thumb in physics. Among the best is: light acts like you’d expect on scales well above its wavelength and acts weird on scales below. In order to take a picture of a thing you need light to bounce.

Basically the only thing they have actually seen is basically a computer image not the real image, and second, they observe electric fields, not the particle itself---they do not observe particles themselves. They are able to observe only the field---however this alone does not prove anything, but that that electric energy fields exist and that’s about---no atoms, no photons, no electrons, no quarks. no nothing. So, no, particles do not exist. Particles exist only inside mathematical abstractions and nothing more and nothing else. We don’t know what actually exists in the real world, except that they are energy fields---electric, magnetic and all other forms and all other kinds of energy fields.

I forgot to add that what exactly is visualized with all these microscopes including STM. What is visualized is the charge density of the electric field.
Basically you observe vibrations----electric vibrations.
You haven’t seen an atom either. You’ve seen an image you assume to be an atom, but it is simply an instrument’s representation of the atom. It is not the atom itself.

Those aren’t actual ATOMS… That is the representation of its effects (measurements).

These techniques aren’t actually “visual” like microscopes we work with in biology classes. Microscopes use lenses and light to help zoom and focus on small objects. Electron microscopes, on the other hand, use quantum scattering theory to construct the shape of small objects, then the data is transferred to a computer to create a model. The wavelengths of visible light ranges on the order of ~370nm to 750nm. These are all MUCH larger than many particles of interest (and way too large to view atoms, which are on the order of Angstroms–0.1nm). Scientists need to be creative to be able to “see” atoms.

The problem with what we think are atoms is exactly about the shorter wavelengths. Sure shorter wavelengths hit something, but what is it?
You cannot know what it is because of the reasons I posted above.

So, no, scanning tunneling microscopes and atomic force microscopes did not prove the existence of atoms.

I love this video series, but this one about defining life seems a bit reductionist. It seems to be concluding that, since everything in the universe is made of the same stuff, either everything is alive or everything is dead.

I was hoping they would lead us to a discussion of emergent properties - the general idea that the whole is often more than just a sum of its parts. There’s something undeniably special about a human being, as it is the only organized collection of matter capable of contemplating its own existence. Suns and nebula don’t do that. Mountains, and trees don’t do that. Ants and chimps don’t do that. Computers don’t do that.

Life is a property that emerges from some comparatively rare and very particularly organized collections of matter we call organisms. In the human organism, that collection of matter has evolved into an pattern with an even more unique and powerful emergent property: sentience. Humans have a sense of history and the future. We seek out patterns of logic and meaning. We make value judgements about our choices. We have awareness of our own mind and recognize this quality in others. We don’t just exist, we contemplate existence itself.

The fact that millions of organisms have life, but only one has this kind of sentience must mean something. It seems purposeful, as if the universe was brought into existence so that existence itself could be understood.

For a science-loving Catholic like me, the emergent properties of life and sentience in the universe, and particularly in human beings, help confirm my belief in God.

What is life?
Life is a very complex string of carbon atoms combined with a whole bunch of other stuff to create something very unique. Some call this stuff "organics". In a sense, being alive is the countinuation of the processes which govern our bodies. When these processes halt, we die. So, what is death?

Most fauna have neurons. They help regulate their bodies, tell them what to do, make them alive. When neurons stop working in fauna, they are certifiably dead. They no longer function. Clinically, a human is declared dead when their hearts stop, or when their brains stop working. This however, is only half true. When the heart stops beating, it stops sending oxygen to the brain. This stops critical functions in the cells of the brain, meaning it cannot work. The processes in the brain cease. It dies. In all living things, when the processes which keep them working cease, that thing is considered dead. This is death.

We call our phones dead when they stop working. We call a battery dead when it stops giving off power since it's chemical processes that create the power cease. With that being said, if we do end up making a sentient computer system, is it alive? No. Because it is not organic. It is not made of carbon atoms linked to each other, whilst also linked to other atoms to crate organic compounds. But just because something isn't alive, doesn't mean it can't die. When such a computer system stops working, it can be considered dead the same way we consider our phones dead, as mentioned above.

So, in a nutshell, life is organics. Death is the ceasing of activities and functions in a given object. And just because something isn't alive, doesn't mean it can't die. So long as something has complex processes, it can die. Stars, phones, batteries...

I don't agree with most of this video. I think first of all, I think asking what life is from the ground up (i.e. looking at cells that make us up to ask what life is) is fallacious. The qualities of the parts do not describe the qualities of the whole. Just because a cell has certain properties does not mean that larger complex living organisms are restricted to the same properties, so trying to describe life in terms of cells and then applying it to us doesn't really cut it.

Next, you assert that the goal of life is to avoid death by creating more of itself so that the DNA (or information) is preserved. What is to say that this is a goal? What makes it any more than something that just happens to be the case when living organisms?

Another issue that stands out to me is that you also seem to have a preconceptualised idea of what life is and what living things are that is throwing everything off balance. You can't say all living things have DNA in them before you have even answered what a living thing is. You can't say that the parts that make up a cell are not alive if you haven't answered what life is. Then using those points to say what life is is just ludicrous. That makes them unsupported premises, which means your conclusion is highly dubious.

Finally, I am not pleased with your statement that it is wrong that life is not fundamentally different from inanimate things because they do not contain a metaphysical property and are not governed by different principles than inanimate objects. I don't necessarily disagree with the conclusion, but you just haven't justified it at all in this video. You have described why the cells that make us up are no different from the cells that make inanimate objects up, and that's fine, but I can't point to a single shred of evidence that you have given that demonstrates that metaphysical entities cannot be in coexistence with a Physical body. "One things for sure" and that's that you need to back up such a big statement before making it.

I have a problem with this kind of reductionist materialism. It basically states that there is nothing in the universe other than matter - which is 'dead'...or is it all 'alive'? We don't know, but to say that matter is the most fundamental state of the universe and there is nothing outside of the realm of matter is nothing more than an assumption; a belief system. We simply do not know.

There is no proof that matter is all that there is. There is, however, evidence that this may not be the case. Working on the open minded assumption that, although we cannot yet see anything which lies outside of the material world, it doesn't mean it isn't there, seems to me the wisest mindset moving forward. Most mainstream science however dismisses the notion of there being anything outside the realm of matter as though it is a foregone conclusion. This is an egregious error.

Human consciousness for example: we do not know what it is, or how it came about, or how it works, yet mainstream science (but not all science) assumes it is generated by the brain despite a vast body of evidence, gathered from rigorous studies conducted over decades in various scientific disciplines, which suggests otherwise. As yet, there has been no meaningful or even sensible rebuttal of this evidence.

I do think the errors of materialism will be gradually rectified though as stronger and stronger evidence surfaces that there may be the existence of something outside/beyond the material world we observe. The evidence is already very strong in my opinion, but it is mostly ignored or ridiculed by the religion that is materialism. Once the materialists open their minds and return to proper science - which looks at all the evidence as thoroughly as possible rather than dismissing the parts of it which don't fit with their worldview - we can move forward properly in the search for answers to the question: what is life?

We seem to ignore the fact that "intelligence" is a universal fact. As soon as you have "life", meaning "something" that can replicate and evolve through chemical or other processes, intelligence automatically WILL appear at some point in time.
Therefore, intelligence is a universal constant no matter where in the universe one is or exists.
There are a number of such universal constants. Ironically and perhaps, unfortunately, stupidity is another such universal constant. But, fear and curiosity are also "universal constants", for example.
Besides, whether one is made out of silicon or carbon, really doesn't matter... if one is capable of replication and evolution, one is alive... and if one can ask the question "am I alive?", one is truly intelligent.
That doesn't answer the question "WHY we are intelligent and what PURPOSE thinking really serves", of course. But that's also an entirely different question...

Greeting everyone. I think it would be a good idea to show an example of simple life, which is about a looping process (a cyclic processor).

Let's use a small electric fan on your desk as an example. If the fan is operating normally, it is"alive". If you stick your finger into a blade, the fan will temporarily suspend operation ("suspended animation"). When you remove your finger, the fan will resume normal operation again (it is alive again). If you significantly damage the fan's components, it will stop permanently (and be "dead", no more spinning). A power supply must exist to drive a processor continuously (it has to eat). In some systems, removing the power supply (in this case, the battery) will also cause damage and kill it. Also, the fan will age over many years, and accumulate enough damage to eventually die of "old age" (it will never spin again).

As strange as it may sound, a fan is a simple lifeform. ;)

I know the video isn't about this, but when I read "Is death real?", it made me think of a question I've had ever since I read about quantum immortality: How do we know that anyone actually experiences death? Yes, people die from our perspective — but does anyone die from their own perspective? Maybe we're all quantum immortals, and when we "die" we actually just shift to a timeline where that didn't happen, living indefinitely and leaving everyone else behind in the timelines where we die, without ever knowing it. Maybe everyone who's ever died is just living in a very different universe right now (probably very advanced if they died a long time ago), oblivious to how their absence is affecting us.

No, there isn't really a difference between being "alive" or being "dead". We are just chemical reactions that continue to happen because that's the way it is. Our consciousness is not really what we think it is, it is just our brain sending electric impulses. To make these electric impulses we need energy, which we get from food. That is why we have a desire to eat.

Cells have a set of instructions and once those instructions are complete (or there is no energy left it feed the cell) it dies. Therefore no more chemical reactions happen.

Now, I don't understand why people can die, as we weren't really ever alive. Using the facts I stated above, we either need to have completed the set of instructions written by our DNA or run out of energy.

To be honest with you, I have no idea if any of this is true. It is just a theory based on my current knowledge of human existence. Any comments are greatly appreciated.

I do think that the distinction between living and dead matter is an artificial one, but from our subjective perspective I think it is an important definition to have. Personally I best like NASA's exobiology definition for life being "a self-sustaining chemical system capable of Darwinian evolution". For example whilst a virus is a chemical system capable of evolution, it is not self-sustained since all of the information required for the collective system to undergo evolution is not contained within the collective system, and it is therefore only a proto life form. Also death only evolved as a certainty for organisms then they differentiated between somatic and germ line cells (with the somatic dying), a bacterium that self replicates is effectively immortal unless actively killed.

I'm very confused :/ I think we must consider dead things (things that were once living then died) to still be life, just none functioning life. Calling a rock dead shouldn't be correct because a rock never lived to have died so it's just inanimate. Once we recognize dead bodies as life it eliminates the paradox I stated before. We can define something as being alive if it is a none static, self-contained array of complex chemical processes and systems capable as a whole of reproduction, adaptation and evolution. Death can then be defined as when these chemical systems cease function and the body becomes static and losses the ability to reproduce, adapt and evolve.

I think that every cell wants to stay alive forever. If they could, they would. But since they cannot and eventually have to die, they choose to create an offspring and pass on their information (DNA) to their offspring, thus ensuring that their memory (or some essence of their existence) still lives in the world, carried by the offspring. Assuming this is true, since this survival instinct is instilled in living organisms on a cellular level, we (and all life), are programmed to survive. Every evolution has happened for a better survival of the organism (flight in birds, camouflage in some animals etc.). So the only purpose of our life is survival? Maybe, life is just a complex set of information of matter and energy aligned together to keep existing. It will keep matter in order and take energy for said information to exist. Death occurs when said information cannot be sustained anymore by its surrounding matter and energy and the information in that particular body is then dissipated back into the environment. This is why life decides to create more bodies or beings, because a particular set of matter has limited energy for it to use and in order for it to keep existing, it needs to use a different set of matter with a different energy potential to continue existing. No system with its own chemical reactions is 100% efficient thanks to entropy, but an ecosphere like earth is a whole system where life forms need each other to recycle the matter for the use of future life, but this ecosphere will not be eternal, but will last a long time. The second reason why life decides to create more bodies is to give itself the chance to adapt to changes in the environment.
That's my thought on life. and had quite the fun thinking about it.

If we really think about it the line that makes living and non living different is complexity and structure.  If you have a bunch of cells which are more complex than a rock for example and those cells form a being then you have more complex life.  Then that organism let's say a cow developes n a particular way that allowes its complex cells to  form a brain then you have semi conscious life.  It forms a psychological model through electric currents and that gives way for that complex structure to make behavioral boundaries for itself (a desire to mate persay).  Then if it gets even more complex you get a special arrangement of cells that form a particular electrical circuit that forms consciousness.  That's what we are.  A complex thing made out of other complex things existing as electrical currents being conducted by complex things making a being that is able to think about its own existence in a way that no other complex thing can.  So to put it simply dead=simple, non self changing, and static.  Alive= complex, self changing and able to form other and more complex things, and it is not static. Take a look at yourself. Everything fits together a little too perfectly, wouldn't you say? Yet some things are jacked up. Like the fact that we die.

Humans have ideas. We have emotions and consciences. Yet we are not all the same, some of us are drastically different than the others. We all have our own identity. Yet no matter how different we are from each other, we have the ability to love and care and give up things for each other. And it's been that way for a heck of a lot of years. It's weird how humans, at the top of the pyramid pretty much everywhere, have the ability to have every quality, yet some animals are able to feel the exact same qualities, such as partnership or mournfulness or happiness. And isn't it strange how there are so many missing links? There seems to be two signs of the evolution process, dinosaurs to everything else. And if dinosaurs already ate and could kill everything, why would they evolve into anything else? Or maybe they were destroyed in a giant explosion. Yet their bones survived. So where did the time go? How come we get fossils from everything except the things that came before our current forms? How come I can draw a colorful picture? How come food tastes so good? How are those things helping me survive? How come depressed people kill themselves? How come I do dangerous things that could mean my life, like eating hamburgers at McDonalds? Why is the dead stuff that makes up my body so infatuated with music? With drawing? With the stars?

Evolution is science fiction. The sooner you understand that, the sooner everything starts to make sense, and you don't have to struggle to come up with an answer to the math and science problems you didn't solve correctly. Go back and check your arithmetic. You made a few simple mistakes.

I suggest praying. For answers. Not to be let into an imaginary heaven so you can sit at the foot of Jesus and do nothing else for the rest of all time.

Answer :
Life is a characteristic distinguishing physical entities having biological processes, such as signaling and self-sustaining processes, from those that do not, either because such functions have ceased, or because they never had such functions and are classified as inanimate. Various forms of life exist, such as plants, animals, fungi, protists, archaea, and bacteria. The criteria can at times be ambiguous and may or may not define viruses, viroids, or potential artificial life as "living". Biology is the primary scienceconcerned with the study of life, although many other sciences are involved.

The core issue is that being alive versus being dead has never been an overt measurement of the universe as a whole, or a property within it. It's an event, local to its descriptions. We describe those around us as "Alive" out of convenience, as we have a vague understanding of life.

The simple solution to this is to accept that life and death are as useful shorthand descriptions of events as descriptions like "You" or "Me". On the level we exist at, on the level we experience, those are useful shorthands for an issue that dissolves both once considered in a different method. It exists as much as "math" does. Very specific rules, that describe a lot of relevant events, but is impossible to dissect for and analyze.

The Life or death doesn't have the answer. In other way, we can't answer the question: What is the life, what is the death?  But, we don't give in, we always research about it. And that subject is philosophy.

1:06 All 'living' things are constructions of 'dead' molecules, temporarily orchestrated by the laws of physics + time.

This is why free will is an illusion. There is no way you or I can control the laws of physics and chemistry that govern the atomic and molecular reactions which control our cells, which in turn cause our brains and bodies to generate our actions, thoughts, and feelings. It is my understanding that all current evidence supports the idea that "You" or "I" (i.e. consciousness) originates in the brain and is generated by it; until we prove otherwise, we cannot claim to be exempt from the observable laws of the universe. There is no evidence, for example, that our decisions are being beamed down as undetectable instructions from our ACTUAL selves (i.e. souls) which reside in a far off place or separate plane of reality where entities can actually interfere with the laws of physics to make decisions of their own. No; consciousness is a RETROACTIVE awareness and ownership of our bodily processes; it's the latest advantageous system that has developed through evolution to better propagate and maintain the information contained within us.

For example, it has led to the advent of written and verbal language, which allows us to teach each other things in a more quickly adaptable way than the instinctual language of dogs or the genetic language of bacteria. This allows our species to expand, build, and thrive in environments previously unsuitable to our ancestors, as knowledge is no longer lost to each successive generation.

I live in a nutshell

The meaning of life, or the answer to the question "What is the meaning of life?", pertains to the significance of living or existence in general. Many other related questions include "Why are we here?", "What is life all about?", or "What is the purpose of existence?" There have been a large number of proposed answers to these questions from many different cultural and ideological backgrounds. The search for life's meaning has produced much philosophical, scientific, theological, and metaphysical speculation throughout history. Different people and cultures believe different things for the answer to this question.

The meaning of life as we perceive it is derived from philosophical and religious contemplation of,about existence, social ties, consciousness, and happiness. Many other issues are also involved, such as symbolic meaning, ontology, value, purpose, ethics, good and evil, free will, the existence of one or multiple gods, conceptions of God, the soul, and the afterlife. Scientific contributions focus primarily on describing related empirical facts about the universe, exploring the context and parameters concerning the "how" of life. Science also studies and can provide recommendations for the pursuit of well-being and a related conception of morality. An alternative, humanistic approach poses the question, "What is the meaning of my life?"

Okay it's quite simple. In our everyday lives the distinction between living and non-living things is of high importance. (same with the human/non-human division) Therefore we biologically acquired a subconscious tendency to draw lines. However this lines do not serve anything but practical purpose. When we examine those lines from a scientific point we understand that the lines are blurred. Then we have two options. 1) to accept that this distiction is nothing more than a practical, evolutionary-developed habit with no application in nature. 2) to engage intense mental-gymnastics in order to create a complex metaphysical theory in order to justify our absurd line-drawing. It is funny to think how many great minds choose the second option in order to avoid the cognitive dissonance caused by the acceptance of how absurd the distinction between living and non-living things is.

The thing that separates living things from dead things is a "soul." ... No, not like "that music's got soul," or "this is my soul-food," but instead like "a person 'has' a soul."

Computers are never going to be "living" things no matter how "imitative" of living things they seem to get because we can't put a soul into, or attach a soul to, inanimate metal and electrical machines. All computers are is a collection of "1's" and "0's" that are programmed in a way to respond to words and phrases the way the programmer told it to.  Even if it "learns" or "changes" its code autonomously, it still boils-down to changing it's response due to a preprogrammed probability of favorable results matrix or other "AI" coding.

Whether other animals have a soul is probable, since they have "feelings" and "emotions," which is something that "living" things do.  A mountain doesn't "hurt," a gem doesn't show "love," and a volcano doesn't have "anger" because they aren't "living." A bird, lion, or whale? Sure! An animal can show affection or get depressed/sad. They have a "soul" that enables them to "experience" life, thoughts, emotions, etc. Talk about bacteria, amoeba, or other really tiny organisms? I don't know, I haven't learned to communicate with them to ask them! ;-)

We can't see or detect a soul using visible means because it's not physical like atoms, quarks, electrons, photons, and the interactions between them. A "soul" doesn't act like a particle, but not like a wave either, it's just there.  Say what you will about the origins of the soul, I can't prove it concretely in a way like the discovery of some new element or interaction of physical things, but we all should realize it's there.  When you see someone that is feeling something (good/bad/whatever) and you say or do something that changes how they are, that's something that's exclusive to living things. In all the universe, only our planet (and any others that contain life that "has a soul") can be called one that has "life."

even though the debate about life and death is important in philosophy and It makes for very stimulating conversations at the academic level, the philosophical definition is somewhat irrelevant to the existence of species (or some form of "biotic" elements that could be defined in infinitely arbitrary ways, since the definition will be constrained by our species-specific consciousness) in the universe. Our interpretations and definitions of biotic vs. abiotic elements are constrained by our our own consciousness and biology and very biased towards abiogenic processes in this planet.

The evolutionary molecular mechanism of our carbon-based life could be completely different in other planets, if evolutionary forces are acting at all upon other entities (in fact, the most basic concept of life as entropy-decreasing, self-replicating entities might not even apply in other species). What we have defined to be "life", "intelligence", consciousness is heavily constricted by the physics of our planet and the particular evolutionary pathway of life on Earth; the fundamental flaw in our thinking about this issue is that we are perhaps more biased than we can currently be aware of.

In my opinion one of the defining characteristics of life is active entropy resistance, or homeostasis. We don't just eat. We eat because entropy robs us of energy and stuff (matter). We need to replace it. Although we constantly change, we are designed to replace lost bits with new bits to try our best to stay the same, and to reproduce. The first life stole chemicals and heat from hydrothermal vents in the ocean, and most land based life steals matter from either each other or from the soil and steals energy either in the forms of heat, chemical (food), or light. We rely on entropy to steal energy and stuff from something and them we robin-hood it back so to speak. All for the purpose of keeping entropy for taking too much of our stuff or energy. Dead things decay, living things resist decay. That is the primary distinction. When our resistance to decay fails or begins to fail. We are dead.

What cannot be denied is that "Life" as we know it is rather chaotic and unpredictable, but it can also be greatly meticulous and attentive to the workings of itself. It can be observed at the microcosm (i.e. atoms, molecules, cells, bacteria, etc.), the macrocosm (i.e. animals, plants, objects, stars, planets, solar systems, etc.), and everything in between. Whether you want to make the argument that there is no meaning to life and everything can be explained scientifically or that there may or may not be an "intelligence" greater than our understanding that we as a society have granted the label of God/Gods. Just remember that we really are a truly limited race of supposedly intelligent beings (at least some of us), yet we're so smug about what we can do to the point of ignorance (when compared to other living things that can't do what we can). I believe that no matter how much we think we've figured things out for ourselves, it is still very likely that something far greater than our comprehension exists beyond our limited conscious awareness. After all, what is free will? What is fate? Imagine if you were given the ability to be indisputably convinced divine intelligence existed, would there ever be a skeptic to criticize it? We cannot possibly know everything, no matter how smug we are about the scientific method, evolution, string theory, and quantum mechanics. The fact of the matter is, not everything is known about the universe and not all things can be tested/detected by humans. Like it or not, we likely aren't the most superior living things to ever exist. Humans make mistakes, its in our nature. Everything "confirmed" by science at this point can still be subject to debate and criticism, just like how religious dogmas and spiritual concepts are capable of being criticized for their validity. Nothing is securely spared from questioning, nothing is 100% infallible.

First of all selection plays a secondary role to ecological interactions and behavior, which is only partially determined by DNA.
And the role natural selection plays is minor role in evolution compared to evo-devo, neo-Lamarckian evolution, and genetic drift. But is still huge for producing adaptations.
Survival of the fittest meme is dogma, for a good look at why that is, and at the current position of evolutionary science I suggest you check out the paper on etho-ecological-morphological mismatches and ONCE published in frontiers in ecology and evolution, January 2017. It's open access and extremely interesting.

Life isn't a material being, it is information acting as constraints that focus matter and entropy into animation in the empty space between the constraints. Said metaphorically, Life is the pot that carries the water. These constraints self replicate(genetics), and change(evolution) and interact via biosemiosis(sign relations) with itself and its environment while traveling in the form of wave packets of constraints (individual organisms). Life on earth is a single, immortal entity, flowing in a dendritic pattern from the time of its emergence. This emerging concept is vitalism, life's vitality is not force, it is constraints that turn entropy into a working mind(complex adaptive system) that reproduces these constraints.

Humans are different from everything else in a few select ways...

Everything, however, is made up of the same 4 nitrogenic bases in different sequence. Due to the laws of energy; stating that it can never be destroyed, only transferred or translated... We (humans and everything else in existence) are all made up of the same material, yes. The same energy, yes.

But just because something is comprised of energy, doesn't mean that it is alive. Living organisms don't NEED to be programmed; they self-program and learn from their environment; adapt and change to maintain survival. Humans then create and thrive---but we're just talking about life and death.

Although it's not nearly as substantial a question, as it doesn't typically have ramifications in the day-to-day, living things are apparent. We cannot appreciate what is alive and what is dead, as we only can pick up on so many frequencies; we are limited to our senses. Although, we may find that we are able to pick up on more frequencies (that it is embedded in our very beings to do so and simply have not become aware of it, let alone mastered it). At this point, our understanding of life will expand.

As for now, if we can sense that it is alive, it is alive. Even if that requires a microscope or some other paraphernalia.

I see it this way guys

Alive: (the state of) an entity made of inanimate/animate material that is able to react or observe its environment to some degree. Living is a complex system, once it ceases being alive ceases. The systems of inanimate and animate material creates the experience of life.

Dead: includes a once animated system of inanimate material that is no longer animate as a whole nor functions as a system that can observe its environment.

Inanimate: entities, particles or systems that are governed by the laws of the universe alone, that which can't observe its environment the way living things do or interact the way living things do. Inanimate material can become animate (carbon eventually becoming a part of reactions or becoming a part of living things).

And friend and I had a two hour long conversation about life and why things happen. Basically the "meaning of life". We thought about the comparison between humans (self-aware animals) and animals (acting by instinct). The purpose of animals is to survive and recreate. A "natural" life. Now, humans mostly don't act by instinct, they are aware of what they're doing, their surroundings, and they know how to change things and what they want (ego). Our purpose is also to recreate, and survive, but not only that: It's also thinking about these things and finding an answer or questions that satisfy us, so that we can die in "peace". This is mostly philosophy, not science. But I think maybe it's going in the right direction. And so, I've kind of fulfilled my purpose - thinking about my purpose and finding an answer I can live with, so that I can be a balanced, healthy member of society, procrastinate and cease in satisfaction and "peace".

I think there's another dual-categorization that makes sense for me.

Speaking about cells, bacteria, plants etc. you're talking about "unconscious" living things.
During Evolution at a certain stage there was something that did not move according to laws. Over a period of time those things evolved imagination, memory and thought and got the ability to "observe and act consequentially", the so called "conscious" living things.

Regarding the question what life is:
I think the essential property which makes a thing living or not is wether something is acting or not.
Not acting in this sense would mean to act according to laws (like dead matter).
Living things are systems that change how itself meaning all it consists of are influenced by the laws of nature.

And here's my problem: Isn't the difference pragmatic?
You basically name the same thing twice. The elements it consits of are dead yet the organisms as whole systems count as living things. Such a differentiation doens't make sense. It would literally mean that all things that exist do live and vice versa, in other words that Existence equals Life.

I think the existence of living organisms is determined by the laws of existence itself and that they are therefore arguably deeply connected to each other.
But I wouldn't go that far to say that all living things necessarily behave according to laws or even to say life is existence.

For my understanding of living you cannot precisely differ it from non living things if you don't consider consciousness.

Compared to our physical world, our mind is something extremely unexplored by science since you can hardly do so in a scientific way. But I would love to see some philosophical and psychological content into that direction!

I think the Mind-Body problem is the core that needs to be solved. Not in the way that Leibnitz famously did it but for real: How do the mind of a thing and the physis interact? I think we may get hints by researching how conscious living has begun

Anyway

Let's say a=b.

a = b
a*a = b*a (multiply both sides with a)
a^2 = ab
a^2 - b^2 = ab - b^2 (subtract b^2 from both sides)
(a - b)(a + b) = b*(a - b) (factor (a-b) on both sides)
a + b = b (divide both sides with(a-b))

But we know a=b, so we can substitute b for a.

b+b=b
2b=b

When I think about evolution and the emergence of the first life and first primitive consciousness I just cant avoid the conclusion that life and "non-life", consciousness and "non-consciousness" might not be as different from each other as we might assume. What we call (seemingly) conscious life is just "dead", non-consious matter arranged in such a way that it produces some sort of "subjective experience" and all this is caused by "dead", naturalistic and therefore deterministic principles which have evolved over very long periods of time to become more conscious, in more complex ways. Still its the same dead, unconscious universe in which all this happens. So consciousness seems to be non-consciousness which becomes less non-conscious through interacting with certain environments. Non-consciousness and non-life therefore can not really be completely non-conscious and dead if you can follow my train of thought. From what I know about the history of the universe, from what I know about physics, chemistry and biology this is the most rational way I can think of how consciousness and life could have emerged. We are either just more conscious, less non-conscious (which probably means the same) or equally as conscious (only with different ways of experiencing and expressing it) than australopithecus, the first mammals, cells, bacteria or even molecules and atoms. We are just currently defining life and consciousness by wrong parameters. We say life is metabolism when metabolism actually is an evoled form of life than existence without biological processes. It seems like the only explanation of what consciousness/life essentially is and what differenciates it from non-consciousness/dead matter. The only problem is that it sounds to me a lot like the new age bullshit "everything is consciousness, everything is life, everything is one" which I dont really regard as being well-reasoned, true and accurate describtions of this universe. This coming from my own reason, please help me if you can!

R-Respiration:Intake of oxygen, Inhaling Excretion of carbon dioxide, exhaling
I-Irritability:The ability to detect Changes in the interior or exterior environment. Often involves change in place/position
N-Nutrition:The Intake of food to supply body with energy to grow.
G-Growth: Growth is the Process in which A part of the body grows in size, (Development)
E-Excretion: The outtake of excess substances such as urine

We have to put things into those boxes. Are hyenas canine or feline? Plants were easy to assign. Viruses are not as easy. RNA and rhybosymes smudges it a little more.
It's simultaneously arbitrary and very important to define.

its due to our language that we create this false distinction between 'dead' and 'alive'. pretty much many people are lazy thinkers, because we judge 'alive' by what is moving as opposed to what is relatively still. The word Animation, comes from a old conscept of soul which is a greek and roman superstition, and now christian. And so we are taught by these religions that there is a fundamental division between 'matter' and 'spirit' which is nonsense as proven here. Even early 19th century science was stuck in this paradigm and still kind of is.. we still teach our children that plants are just cold lifeless balls of rocks, which if your following me is still the same assumption that religion takes about what is living and what is not and these conclusions are pretty much assumptions based on ignorance that if its not moving the way the human eye perceives it somehow 'soulless'
ie not 'alive'. Its actually a very interesting subject and it plays a lot on our psychology in the way we perceive and relate to our world.
