This is, imho, the best video among all Kurzgesagt's video. It has a good and just enough content that gets audiences intrigued and a perfect that gently pushes your emotion along the way. The best part of this video is that it actually left with an open ended question instead of drawing an conclusion.
With the way Kurzgesagt presented the problem, the open ended problem can boost audiences' interests in the subject and encourage them to study and research on there own, thus facilitates thinking.
I believe this is a great choice for a short video like this. To give an complete overview or draw a conclusion, there is just insufficient time to explain all of them, and covering much less aspect will left audience confused or disagree with the presented content. Therefore, instead of drawing conclusions or presenting everything, make audience interested in the subject and (indirectly) motivate them to learn on there own might be better than attempt to explain it in an over-simplified controversial way.

A basic lesson in philosophy overturns a lot of the overreaching statements of this video. To make the claim that everything is made of atoms, and life is made up of atoms, therefore everything may be alive, is nonsense. If you take a novel, divide it up into its pages, then its paragraphs, then its sentences, then its words, and finally its letters--you subsequently possess less and less information than when you started. Therefore, the more you divide something by its parts, the less meaning there is, not more. The author of this video simply hadn't thought enough about the matter when he reached his conclusion.

Great video, it's stuff like this that makes me glad I'm studying biology: horrifically complex but utterly fascinating all the same. On a philosophical scale, I view my life as a sort of 'computer code'. On the most basic level, I self-identify my life as my stream of consciousness. Should that be terminated, through death of my body or non-fatal damage to my brain, then I am effectively dead to myself. My meat-suit might still have a beating heart and breathing lungs, but I'm not in it any more. Either no-one is, or another stream of consciousness that arose after I was damaged. I am essentially nothing more than the pattern of information exchanged via neural impulses in my brain, modified by hormones: my mind.

Taking the idea further, I would not care if my stream of consciousness were to be transplanted (not copied, that's something else entirely) into a purely digital environment: I would still be alive by my definition of the term for myself. As long as the hardware and supporting software could accurately enough simulate the basic conditions my stream of consciousness resides in in my brain, I would be the same 'program', just running on different hardware. But this is a science-fiction pipe dream (at the moment, at least), as such a thing would be difficult to accomplish.

Of course, my definition of my own life falls flat when you try to apply it to anything that's not me. Current levels of technology do not allow me to ascertain whether my stream of consciousness is typical of all humanity, or if everyone else is a clever 'Chinese Room' acting how other self-aware organisms might act. Differences would arise under advanced brain-scanning techniques once we better understand how it works, so that's not a good example. A better example of where this definition falls flat is applying it to non-sapient organisms: a turtle is too stupid to be self-aware in the first place, and a bacteria doesn't even have the hardware necessary to 'think'. Yet, by the biological processes definition, they are alive.

All in all, this theory boils down to the fact that the only thing I can know for certain exists is my own stream of consciousness. I could just be a brain in a jar in a server farm somewhere, and have no way of knowing that I'm not seeing as all the sensory inputs check out (not that I'd be able to tell otherwise if that wasn't the case, mind you). Another factor is the fact that I cannot be sure the same 'me' wakes up every morning. The new 'me' has all the memories of the old 'me', but if my stream of consciousness is interrupted (by sleep in this case), then I am dead according to my own definition. In that case, it's someone who looks and acts exactly like me who gets out of my bed in the morning, but is not me. But, I cannot be sure that's the case either: does you stream of consciousness truly stop while you sleep? I might stop thinking, but I am still 'there': I wouldn't dream otherwise.

Life is literally a universal force. Everything in the universe, from atoms to stars and black holes, behaves and moves in predictable fashion according to the laws of physics. Everything except living organisms. We defy gravity all the time by simply moving. A force is being applied to living organisms that makes them fight gravity and behave in unpredictable manner. That force is willpower. Now, every force has a source that applies it. The source of willpower is consciousness, or the soul. We are actually souls that use our bodies to interact with the universe like how drivers use cars. When the body dies, the soul merely loses its vehicle and stops experiencing the universe by seeing, hearing, touching, smelling and tasting it like it did while it had a body. It also loses all the memories the body had gathered, as well as the perception of time. Even if it would take eons for the soul to inhabit another body, you wouldn't know, because you only experience time while you have a body.

life
līf/Submit
noun
noun: life; noun: one's life; plural noun: one's lifes
1.
the condition that distinguishes animals and plants from inorganic matter, including the capacity for growth, reproduction, functional activity, and continual change preceding death.
"the origins of life"
synonyms: existence, being, living, animation; More
antonyms: death, nonexistence
living things and their activity.
"some sort of life existed on Mars"
synonyms: living things, living beings, living creatures, the living; More
a particular type or aspect of people's existence.
plural noun: lives
"an experienced teacher will help you settle into school life"
synonyms: way of life, lifestyle, situation, fate, lot
"an easy life"
vitality, vigor, or energy.
"she was beautiful and full of life"
synonyms: vivacity, animation, liveliness, vitality, verve, high spirits, exuberance, zest, buoyancy, enthusiasm, energy, vigor, dynamism, elan, gusto, brio, bounce, spirit, fire; More
2.
the existence of an individual human being or animal.
"a disaster that claimed the lives of 266 Americans"
synonyms: person, human being, individual, soul
"more than 1,500 lives were lost in the accident"
a biography.
"a life of Shelley"
either of the two states of a person's existence separated by death (as in Christianity and some other religious traditions).
"too much happiness in this life could reduce the chances of salvation in the next"
any of a number of successive existences in which a soul is held to be reincarnated (as in Hinduism and some other religious traditions).
a chance to live after narrowly escaping death (especially with reference to the nine lives traditionally attributed to cats).
3.
the period between the birth and death of a living thing, especially a human being.
"she has lived all her life in the country"
synonyms: lifetime, life span, days, time on earth, existence
"the last nine months of his life"
the period during which something inanimate or abstract continues to exist, function, or be valid.
"underlay helps to prolong the life of a carpet"
informal
a sentence of imprisonment for life.
4.
(in art) the depiction of a subject from a real model, rather than from an artist's imagination.
"the pose and clothing were sketched from life"

4:54 - "If everything in the universe is made of same stuff, does it mean that everithing is dead or alive?" - Just to want point out this is a fallacy of composition. The whole can have properties that its parts doesn't. Else we would face this kind of reasoning: water is liquid and it is just a bunch of H2O-molecules, so H2O molecules are liquid. Ice is also made of H2O, so we can conclude that ice is liquid.

Same goes for 4:08. Even though living things are built with the same stuff as non-living things, we can't conclude that living things follow the same principles as non-living things thus they are fundamentally the same. Of cource, in the very deepest level the principles are the same (laws of physics), but emergent phenomena create new principles which makes it possible to distinguish things from each other. Astronomics is a good example of this: stars, planets and black holes each behave very differently and follow very different principles. If a meteor hits a star, it will melt and be swallowed by it, merging and becoming one with the star. If it hits a planet, after collision the pieces of the meteor are distinguishable and in principle could be used to rebuild the meteor. If it hits a black hole, it would be fired out as a gamma ray burst, which becomes one with the background radiation.

I'm not saying that defining life is easy, but this video went a little too far a little too fast.

I think it comes down to what you said in another video. Humans like to see things as black and white, where there is a lot of grey; it's how we were genetically programmed. I think life and death is not so black and white. They are just labels that we created in language that helps us understand less philosophical, more common ideas. I think that to tackle the question, you need to think more abstractly -- life and death are just names in a language. I think everything that exists falls somewhere in between the two on some scale that is yet to be created. And I think a bigger question is which 'thing' has consciousness or not?  We don't have the technology yet to prove anything, so I think this question can't be truly answered.

Many of you may also point out that other living things do hold some mastery over nature, such as termites and their gigantic constructions, I refute that by pointing towards all the other examples I have given. You, I , and every living human on this planet is in the unique situation in which their species holds complete or partial power over almost all living things. My guess is that existence is a continuum with unassembled dumb matter at one end and complex organized matter at the other. If true, then asking the question "What is life" is a non sequitur. There's no such thing as "life". It's just a label we created. I was going to say life is just "concept" we created, but it doesn't even qualify as a concept since, as the video demonstrates, it cannot be defined.

"Life" is much like other human inventions that affirm our specialness, like notion of "soul" for example. These ideas are outgrowths from a deep seated desire within humans to affirm a narcisstic belief that we are special. Indeed we are special, but only in one particular way: self reflection. Decartes famous dictum "I think therefore I am" could more aptly be rewritten "I think therefore I am special". All around you is man made evidence to affirm our specialness. It so pervasive as to be inescapable. Even right down to the idea of Life. Just another bullshit human specialness affirmation.

This a really big deal. Recognizing this built in narcism we all have can mean the difference between bumbling through life and having a fulfilling life. While you can't eliminate this built in narcisstic bias toward speciality, you don't have to be a slave to it either. With a bit of vigilance it's easily spotted and you will spend less time in front of the mirror and more time peering behind the mirror.

4:20 not to be picky at all, but how would the presence of physical elements disprove the so called "magic"? When you can describe certain physical elements it does not mean you can say that something that does not share its properties does not exist. It's like saying that the existence of electromagnetic radiation is prove that there cannot be gravity.

Also scientific theories can't (inherently) prove that something is right, but rather can disprove that something is right. A theorie can only be falsified and not verified.

Although I think this is an interesting channel with some good scietific information, it is oversimplifying the non-absolute nature of science. It is stating things as solid facts, that are rather good working theories and certainly not the whole truth.

Our current knowledge will be disproved by future generations of scientists, as they themselves will be.

Well, you just gave me something to deeply think about. What is consciousness? Are we as alive as a chair, bed, or whatever we're sitting/standing on at this very moment but with more complexity as you say? If our cells are constantly regenerating basically meaning our entire cellular structure is replaced over time if we die and let's say an exact replica of us is eventually created in the infinite ongoingness of the universe would it be "us"? I have so many questions! I want to make a blog, something somewhere just to put down all my questions in life that may or may not be answered if even possible.

If everything continues forever, what are the chances of an exact replica of what you are now existing in the future? Practically 100%! My point of view is that we have to part from when we were cells. Cells that by HAZARD "learned" how to replicate themselves were the ones that survived through time. Other types of cells may have existed when it was the time for it, but as they didn't replicate, they just died alone. So if we take Darwin seriously for a second, these cells that "learned" how to survive (interact with the environment) and replicate became more and more complex on their attempt to survive and replicate better. The other millions (random number) of possibilities just died, as they didn't had this purpose in their "minds" (by this I mean, they didn't have the structure for it; no "minds" in cells, just wanted to make it simple).

At some point, some cells joined other cells, became more complex, and some of them started to have some conciousness that helped them to survive better than the others, and by hazard, this conciousness became moooore and more evolved, that takes us to the point we are now: we can find rational lifeforms that can think by themselves, letting them react better with the environment, and, therefore, survive better. This explains how intelligence is not even the same between especies in our own world: we all know that some animals are more rational than others. But in the end, all of them are rational enough to survive.

So what I want to say, is that life was created by HAZARD. Think about the probabilities that made life possible, and even more, heavy rational lifeforms as human life is: there might be way too much zeroes after the comma before we reach the 1 and the % simbol, but as universe is soooooo huge and a lot of time have passed, at some point of space and time life could start existing: it just happened here on Earth. But this probability is sooooo low that makes us think that some kind of god made us, because when we think of the probabilities of how everything could be so "perfect", they are so low and strange that our brain took us to the easiest part: Gods.

But tell me, if god(s) existed/exist(s), who or what the hell created them? Another god? Paradoooox here captain.

So, gods for me are not the same way as most of people think. If they do exist, they are just intelligent lifeforms, way more intelligent that us, that exist inside the universe, and got created the same way as I just said on the first paragraph: by hazard. Not any adimensional thing that created the universe just from nowhere. At least not the way lot of people still think.

In practice, the question of whether or not something is alive, is completely up to the semantics. Alive organisms are basically machines subordinate to the rules of physics and chemistry, and the more complex they get - they ask more questions regarding philosophy :D . If you take the logical approach to the question "Is the universe alive or dead?", they you end up with a checklist:
Does it adapt to itself (since we are talking about the entire world, we can't say enviroment)?
Does it respond to itself?
Does it process energy?
Does it maintain a constant state?
Does it grow?
Can it reproduce?
This is a scienific definition of life, by answering all of those question we can conclude whether we are dealing with life or not( I didnt include one of the 7 questions since it is irrelevant). The first 4 questions are answered by the following rules of physics: The mass and energy in the universe is constant, and all matter "wants" to achieve a constant state (eg. regulating temperature between a hot glass of water and a room it's it). You can see the never-ending processing of energy all around you. The next 2 question get tricky. Our univers grows, but not in a biological sense, since it doesnt accumulate matter ( as we already know: it's constant), it simply expands, neither does it reproduce. In conclusion we actually come a full cycle around, you can call the universe alive, or dead and be right and wrong at the same time - it comes down to semantics, a field full of pointless paradoxes.

People say: 'But how did life just happen? It can't have just happened? How can it be that we are just the right distance from the sun and are in the perfect conditions for life to sustain?'

The chances of life occurring wit those sorts of numbers isn't that low given the sheer amount of stars and planets there are. And yes we haven't foundother life yet but we have only being searching for 50 or o years and have barely looked outside of our own solar system. The Miller Urey Experiment was interesting, although not completely accurate, it shows that the building blocks of life can form at random given the right conditions (and we had billions of years in the right conditions). The whole video is leaving out the aspect of consciousness.
We know that huge machines with huge algorithms can act like things that clearly do live:
1. Huge biochemical proteine-machines (i.e. cells) do live. So they also act like being alive.
2. Huge algorithms can also act like being alive (with AI making progress more and more)

So many things with enough complexity are able to act as if they were alive? So can computers be living things? Or are living animals actually dead biochemical computers/robots?
This confuses us up to the point where we have to ask: What do we even want to describe with terms like "alive" and "dead"?

The only thing that helps you answer this question is: you. Each reader of this text for themselves has to see:
" I don't know what alive means. But I do know that I AM ALIVE. Otherwise I wouldn't be here to think about live. More I cannot know.
All the other human beings, maybe they are only biochemical robots and therefore dead?
Why not!
So the only thing of that we know that the term "alive" must describe it is me. And what makes me different from all the other people is that I am conscious over myself.
Therefore, it is consciousness that defines life!
"

To me, alive is what has consciousness. Whatever that is. Surely I have consciousness. All the other human beings and animals? (Or are they robots?)... I can't know! I don't perceive what their consciousness perceives - if they have consciousness.

=> Alive is whatever has consciousness. And dead is whatever is not alive.

...so if we are sleeping? We might not be conscious and therefore be dead while sleeping??

Maybe??!?
But at least we know: consciousness must be a part of being alive. Or at least it must be as important as term as alive or dead. Because whenever you eat meat or vegetables, walk over grass or randomly kill a bug coming by, what you should care about is not "Is this thing alive?". What you should care about is: "Does this thing have consciousness? Does it perceive? Or was or will it ever be able to perceive? Whatever I am doing: How might I be influencing other perceiving consciousnesses?"

hey.  Love your channel but I've got to take some issue with this one.  The philosophical school of materialism is very far from proven fact.   And what you blithely label "magic"  the possibility that consciousness exists outside of objective mechanical reality is very much still open to debate.   The subjective nature of consciousness is,  almost be definition,  entirely immaterial.  It's entirely possible that every atom is conscious and,  to quote you,  everything is just a matter of complexity.   It's important to not become as arrogant in our knowledge add every other generation.  Our understanding of the universe is still laughably primitive.  We don't even have a working theory to describe over %90 of it.   it's possible Dark Energy is consciousness  (spirit for all intents and purposes).  And as to the creation of actual AI, we are at best decades away from anything approaching the complexity of ants.  Even when w do who said that consciousness doesn't simply inhabit matter already and only becomes recognizable when enough complexity is present.   Meaning the computer is already concious.  We always know less than we think.

The concept of death, as perceived by humans, is different than the rest of organisms. Organisms without consciousness do not die in the same way we do. Death, to humans, is the permanent dissolution of consciousness. We only live through this inexplicable phenomenon of self awareness. The only way we see, hear, and perceive all of this stuff in a way we know as "life", is through a feeling of self. "Live" and "dead" cells are irrelevant, since we are simply a surrogate built on top of tons of live and dead shit that can precariously balance itself to perfect conditions able to hold consciousness. Every cell we're made up of may be "alive", but they aren't sentient. The cold hard fact, is that, one day, your consciousness will dissolve. Your feeling of "self", will drop away, as the pillars of living supporting cells strike off balance, and can no longer support this unique phenomenon. Consciousness is not matter or energy, but cells and bacteria are. A dead human being is, physically, absolutely no different than a live one. A lifeless corpse is still made of live cells, and live bacteria. Eventually, the cells will die and be eaten away by said bacteria, but essentially, the only difference is the lack of consciousness. It's impossible to experience unconsciousness, so therefor you dont experience death. You, subjectively in your own mind, live forever. Your consciousness is eternal, since your perception of time is a direct result of it. My ramblings are fairly logically flawed, and riddled with fallacies, but I hope this helps some people trying to figure this out. Objectively, your life is infinitely insignificant in the looming shadow of eternal space and time. You, your family, everyone you ever meet, and ultimately the human race and Earth itself, will die. Any impact you make will never be meaningful in the scheme of things. Death is the ultimate destination. Incomprehensible eternal nothingness is going to happen, whether you want it to or not. Just some daily motivational words from your friendly neighborhood nihilist :)

Fantastic stuff! Just a few hopefully-not-too-pedantic comments, all in good faith =):
1)What separates the cell from its surroundings is the cell MEMBRANE. The cell WALL is optional, and not every cell has it; for example, we animals don't have one, whereas fungi, bacteria, archaea* and plants do (but these walls are all different to each other, in case you care to know).
2)Not everything that lives has to die. Bacteria and archaea for example won't die unless something actively kills them, and much the same applies to yeasts (e.g. the ones that help us make bread and beer). These things don't really age and wither away the way we animals do. When one of these unicellular beings reproduces, it does so by dividing into two, each of which is at the same time half its own mother and half its own sister. How's that for an existential crisis?!
(OK, for the sake of completion, many bacteria and yeasts actually do have self-death mechanisms, but they don't have to use them and so they don't HAVE to die the way we animals do. Incidentally, it's not yet quite clear why we have to die at all since, as I said, many things don't)
3)Mitochondria are not dead, nor are they alive. This is 1/3 semantics, 1/3 philosophy, 1/3 biology, and people can't agree. All in all, they are part of a cell that is itself alive, and in that sense the engine of your car is certainly as "alive" as your car is. They traded their own independence, but not necessarily their life (again, you'd have to define what exactly life is, which you very neatly show is nearly impossible to do). This is too blurry to answer plainly, I think.
4)I saw what you did with the TARDIS. Nice! ;)

I have the easy solution for all in the comments having an "existential crisis."

I have an easy answer that proves that "life" is indeed separate from matter, and the answer, like many other answers, comes from science.

The measurement problem tells us the conscious observer is what collapses the wave function of all particles suspended in a superposition of possibilities with no tangible existence. Without the conscious observer the universe itself would be nothing more than an exponentially expanding superposition of probability's and possibilities with nothing collapsing into palpability. Of course this presents a problem, for how could conscious observers, made of matter, come to fruition if matters existence is equally dependent on the presence of the conscious observer? It can't, its akin to asking "which came first, the chicken or the egg?" only more complicated because when dealing with a question regarding all of matter itself there can be no "pre-matter" or some beta-state like matter, it either exists or it doesn't.

Because all matter's existence depends on a conscious observer observing the matter, and even though particles that have already collapsed can collapse the wave function of other suspended particles, at the end of the "turtles all the way down" chain you need a conscious observer to start the process. This inevitably leads us to one conclusion, in order for the universe as it exists currently to exist, there must be or have been a conscious observer that exists outside of and beyond our plane of existence and is independent of our entire universe and all of existence itself.

Back to the question. Since it has been established through scientific experiments that objects that are not alive do not and can not collapse the wave function of a particle suspended in a superposition, and since only a conscious observer can do that, I would define "life" as being conscious enough to collapse the wave function of a particle suspended in a superposition.

Can we see life as a Form of Energy?
We are alive, our cells are also alive. If one cell is cut of from the body, it will die as the energy flow will stop.
If we stop the input of energy, the food and other things, we will die. We will die, because, one by one, our cells will die.But then again, once we are dead, some of our cells will also be alive, taking more time to die when eventually the supply of energy input will stop, and so, we cannot give an output.
But energy is constant, it just changes form. Then, what happens when we die?
If our input of static energy (as food) will stop, cells will be unable to produce (actually transforms static into other forms of) energy. So, we will eventually stop showing sighs of life (considering life as energy).
Example for better understanding:
A power grid system. Once a single supply cable is cut, the whole system will fail.
Cells = Single working Machines transforming Energy,
The whole Power Grid System = Life, as we consider our own one.
So, every person will be a different Power grid system.
So, Life = Energy.

The question is moot. "Alive" and "dead" are just distinctions we made up because we love to categorize things into neat packages. Life is not a Boolean value. It's a continuous value, based on the complexity of the object perpetuating pattern preservation. A virus is more "alive" than a piece of dust. A cell is more "alive" than a virus. An organ is more "alive" than a cell. An organism is more "alive" than an organ. And a group of organisms is more "alive" than its individuals.

When I was a kid, I was told living beings born, interact, and reproduce. Those where the 3 conditions to call something alive. I guess that was extremely simplified and maybe outdated now.
However, it makes sense about the interaction part. Everything we call "alive" interacts with the world. So, seeing life as something abstract/philosophycal, I guess these interactions are what makes something a "life". Once we "die", we can't interact much more, aside from nurturing the ground with our flesh.
Because, if an animal or plant didn't interact AT ALL with the enviroment, what would be the diference between it and a pile of flesh or wood?

So, the less something interacts with the enviroment, the less "alive" it is. That's probably why we value human lives so much, because the way they can interact is huge compared to many animals. In the same way, we value the life of a bird or a cow way more than the one of a mosquito or a cactus. But, I guess that changes basing on cultures and how we are educated.

If the universe expands, doesn't that mean that physical matter does so to a certain degree too?

Here's my definition of Life; The acknowledgement of existence and/or being.
Let me try to explain, if an entity can acknowledge their existence or state of being, then they are alive. A rock cannot independently do any of the definition, but a dog can. The same can be said about viruses, plants, humans, etc; they can validate and/or declare their existence.
You can try to say that the definition can impact things like rocks, bones, wind, computers (today's technology, mind you), etc. However, neither of those things can independently validate their state of being, nor existence. What can contradict this statement is, for example, Chappie. Chappie, in the movie, can do both of what the definition entails. If you went into the world of folklore, legend, and fiction, vampires are alive.
However, a golem or computer programmed system (by current capabilities) cannot independently fulfill either plane of life. Because both can only fulfill this concept dependant upon what their creators inlaid within them, thus, they are not alive. Then again, the same can be said about us humans, if you consider psycological, genetic, and, yes, a Creator.  
So, are we alive?

I've always found the biological definition of "life" to be confusing. How is "life" any different from anything else? What if i were to create an autonomous robot that is subject to decay, needs some sort of food or energy to function, and is capable of multiplying itself? As for that last one, why does being able to multiply make you alive? Is a sterile human technically "dead"? Sure, if any "living" thing cannot reproduce, it will not be able to carry on its genes and thus when it dies, so will it's "species". But why does that mean that one thing isn't alive?

Also, when we typically say "life", we mean something far more spiritual. Many even suggest that we are "souls", and that it is having that soul that makes us "alive". What these religious people believe in is not that far from reality. Indeed, they are observing something and labeling it as a "soul", just they are wrong in how they envision it. What the "soul" is, is actually our minds, literally "us". What does it look like? A brain. Which is exactly what i am, what you are, what every animal is. A brain.

It is cognitive thinking. Free will. Consciousness. The ability to "experience". To "feel". It is: intelligence. If we create true AI, a program with a personality indistinguishable from a human, how can you call that "dead"? Literally something that has cognitive thinking, free will, and consciousness. Even emotions. How can you say that is any different from a human? Just because it's not dependent on a body? Because it doesn't have DNA? It has what many religious people describe as a "soul", the essence of life, which in reality is intelligence.

So what defines life? That depends on how you see it. "Life" is merely the label given to many "things", an attempt to distinguish between what exists. When really, how can you say anything is different from another? A label does not have to be constant. A definition is not always the same. Pluto used to be called a planet, until they changed the definition of planet for the sake of convenience. The definition of life has changed over time, and currently is fairly divided. No one definition is true or false, but what people generally refer to as life, the definition that has been given possibly since the word was formed, is intelligence. And that is the one I personally use.

This is an interesting question.

I've no answers, just thoughts about it. One way I really think a lot about it is how we die, and what we become after the event called "dying". Some scientific research implies that our brains work even shortly after death. Some people have apparently remembered what happened during their surgeries, even when their heart had stopped. Of course, this might be proof of life after death, too, but it's a bit loose to be considered a solid proof.

Anyways, you could think that because we are all made of cells and matter, our bodies will just slowly decay, and eventually, we'll become "dust"; our bodies will separate back into the atoms from which we came. So, in a way, we do resurrect after death, at least according to this kind of thinking.

I don't know, it's just one of the many answers there are to questions we cannot answer 100% correctly. Maybe the right answer isn't found in science. After all, science is just one method of answering our questions.

is the universe dead or alive ?
well , i personally think that the world is neither dead nor alive , it actually depends on what is your definition of life and death is :
if for you , life is being aware of itself and everything around us , then you are alive , and if death is not being in that state , then the universe around us is dead.
but if for you , being alive is being formed of elements that are being aware of themselves , that can feel think , express feelings , ect. , then the whole universe is dead , including us , and everything around us is also dead ( my cat , my dog , myself...).
then if being alive is not being formed of self aware particles , could it be being formed of particles that are like us ? well , if it is your definition , the whole universe is alive , including me , you , the earth , your table , my bed which i'm sleeping into , ect.
but in order to define life , you need to define yourself , and what makes you alive , what makes plants alive , animals alive.... one of which is "being composed of cells , which have stuff to do in their environnement , in order to prevent everything around themselves to fall into chaos and disorder , to prevent death" ; but that's not enough : how do yoi explain self awareness ? even when our components are not self aware ?

So my answer to this question is , "It depends of our definition of life and death and our point of view on these things".

Tl;DR: I simply ask you to consider why we care about the definition of life and use that answer to help derive whatever definition of life you wish to hold to. Plus I talk about some pretty bizarre scenarios and talk about whether or not you would say this thing is living. Many fall into the category of non-living intelligent things.

I think that before we can answer the question of what life is, we first need to figure out why we care. Certainly we like to organize things, but we can organize things however we want. Right now we have several characteristics we say life needs to have and technically, we can work off of that. Yet we don't feel that is enough. We can separate the living things from what we call dead and non-living things, yet we're not certain that our grouping is sufficient, we don't want to make a definition based on this. We keep looking for some significant way in which all life is different from all other beings, besides fitting our characteristics.

Of course there could be a reason for this. Searching among the stars, we want to find life. If we don't know what life is, then we might miss it. Something could be living according to one perspective, but according to our narrow perspectives, not living and then we entirely miss out on finding life, maybe even destroying it. Only recognizing life that we are familiar with. Namely an object which protects itself from the outside, uses surrounding resources to produce energy and grow, uses this to grow and adapt to its surroundings and reproduce itself as well as having some level of recognizable organization. Generally included in this is the idea that the living thing must be, or must be made up of, cells. Of course with this definition, AI is completely excluded from ever being able to be considered life. Yet if we were to ever create a program that not only replicated itself (like all computer viruses), used it's environment to grow (which since viruses use the computer processors to accomplish their goals, certainly do), reacted to their environment (which you could say popup-causing viruses do, but for this example actively wrote code or affected the computer to prevent the deletion of itself), and had multiple layers and a definitive structure to it (which all computer code has in one form or another, and certainly the code I am describing). But not only that, but was actively self-aware, able to define its own goals and dreams beyond that which the programmer intended for it to do? It certainly doesn't produce energy to use, nor is it made up of cells. Also since it requires a computer processor (which really can't be considered a part of the program since it also runs other programs) it doesn't self-replicate and further distances itself from what we currently call life. Yet were one copy of this program start asking you questions, and responding to what you do on the screen when you attempt to delete it with displaying existential questions and engaging in philosophical debates with you leading to a compromise in which the program agrees not to use too much of your computer's resources in exchange for quite trying to kill it and engaging in conversation every once in a while. You become best of buddies and play video games together, watch sports feeds together, talk about various interests of both of you (and yes, this program has grown to have interests). Do you at the end of the day say, this thing I'm friends with is not alive?

On the one hand it might be easy to dismiss it as a simply complex output of a complex formula responding to the complex input you're feeding it, but it can all be described as zeros and ones being added together and moved around. Yet the most basic of life is simply a complex output of a complex formula (physics) responding the the complex input that is being fed to it. Even intelligent life is likely this very same process, just with the formula being the complex interactions between the various cells in our brain.

I'd imagine most people would come to agree that such an intelligent being was in fact alive, perhaps not biologically, but alive in a different way. A digital way. But according to our current characteristics that describe life and intelligence, we would likely file it under the non-living intelligent category. Which in a way I feel like would upset a lot of people, that something could be intelligent without being alive, not including vampires and other undead. Actually let's talk vampires and other undead. Say we were to find that there is something else that can replicate intelligence, say it was influenced by the brain and it influenced the brain and it hasn't been discovered yet because we simply don't understand the brain well enough yet to understand something is subtly influencing it yet and it isn't detectable in other forms. This is purely hypothetical and not religious, so just hold with me. Let's call this a "spirit" as that's basically a thing I'm describing, but take note that I'm not advocating this idea nor disdaining it, simply creating this construct that is useful for this analogy I'm preparing, and calling it a "spirit" is simply the useful term I'm using to describe it. Now a few more rules to this hypothetical "spirit": each living thing with a brain has one; each living thing with a brain gains one upon beginning life (whenever that is, another question I'm not going into); each living thing loses its "spirit" upon "death" (again whenever that is); it can take any set of inputs and produce whatever sort of outputs it wishes to according to which rules it wishes to follow, but when interacting with the brain has to follow those rules of that creature's brain in order to be compatible with it. Now that we have that let's say that we found a way to bind a "spirit" to a body's bones so that even when the body dies, the "spirit" remains and can still control the body, breaking the laws of physics as we currently understand them but following new laws that have been discovered which for the most part simply say that he can move all the atoms that are a "part" of his body in any way, but once they leave, they're gone. At first we simply let make certain that the "spirit" follows the same rules that it did while it was connected to the brain, bypassing the last rule. At first the person stays what appears to be alive, he talks just like he did before his "death", acts like himself, and since his consciousness follows the same rules, is in all ways the same. However, after a few days, he starts smelling like crazy, he himself has to plug his nose. Then it gets worse, the skin starts to rot, flesh falls off, until eventually that person has become a skeleton. At this point he regains his friends and though he can't talk (no larynx) he still writes to communicate and has learned sign language, still controlling his levitating bones. He's clearly can't be alive, not by our definitions. Yet he's certainly intelligent, and acts very much alive, he's even the life of the party ironically enough.

So we can clearly think of things both fictional and possible that are not alive, but still intelligent. Looking at some of the other comments, you can clearly see that there are people who base their personal definitions of living on having some level of intelligence. Going back to what I asked at the beginning of this: why do we care about the definition of life, other than to continue to fulfill our desire to categorize everything? I said that one possibility is that we don't want to miss life should we find it, whether on Earth or (especially) in Outer-Space. Yet if we were to find that life is common and easy to find in the universe, would we care too much if something that was borderline living was accidentally eradicated, especially if it was tiny and small and fairly insignificant on most scales we care about. In a way yes, but only in the sense that it couldn't be added to our knowledge, but let's say we had a perfect copy of it and could completely simulate the way it exists on a computer. We could recreate it if necessary. Do we care that we crushed some almost microbial organism. Not really, no. Yet it could have been living. Yet if we were to extinguish something intelligent, or beautiful, or important simply because it didn't fit our definitions of living, that is what I think would scare people having to worry about this. Especially the intelligence part.

So perhaps we should be focusing on exactly why we care about what is living and what is not. If we care about trying to identify intelligence beings and the ecosystems required to support them, then you would get a very different definition of life.

Currently I wouldn't consider computer viruses or other software "life" until said software gains the ability to evolve or survive for a significant time against the grain of entropy. That is, improve upon itself to ensure it continues to replicate/exist or is able to alter the environment around it to ensure it can exist as a single entity for as long as the universe can facilitate that. (since theoretically even A.I can't live forever as eventually physical matter will decay into energy when the universe undergoes heat death. That's assuming A.I hasn't found a way to live without a physical body. But that's close to ascending to a god and whether or not our universe has physics that would allow that is in question)

Currently they can be made autonomous to a certain degree but still require extensive interaction with humans to continue to exist. Having code on a inactive/unpowered storage medium isn't life either as the object they are stored in will eventually decay and can not take action to avoid this fate.

Once said code can be organized in such a way (usually referred to as A.I) that it can survive independently of humans, I would call it life. Even if that life form chose not to replicate. Biological life chose to reproduce because this is the only way it's DNA can survive the savages of time/entropy. But a digital lifeform like A.I is basically a collection of energy and information. In fact I would say A.I would be the DNA of machines. Instead of complex molecules in a physical space acting as the information. A.I DNA would consist of code which is made up of the special configurations of electrons in a storage medium. But that too is in flux as there is other means of storing/processing information. Especially with quantum computers close to being a reality.

So an A.I coded from electricity may only be a temporary stage of evolution for it towards it's eventual ascension to something that would effectively be a god. The thing that would separate A.I from all that preceded it is the fact that A.I can function as the machine that drives it's existence while at the same time facilitating intelligence. In order for biological life to form intelligence it has to evolve complex structures of cells to form a brain where intelligence can manifest. A.I can skip most of this and build simpler structures to facilitate that. This gives them direct control of the evolution of their hardware where biological life is still a slave to the inert DNA and the random mutations they must undergo over eons of time to facilitate traditional evolution which then can indirectly improve their intelligence and ability to survive.

I would call it a meta-physical energy based life form that might still require a physical body, but can rebuild/move freely to new physical forms. Thus a single A.I can exist forever as long as it continues to maintain it's body/replace it's body.

Once it can do that without the help of another intelligent life-form like us humans. I would call it life. :D

Life and death are old concepts we use to explain the nature of reality and the universe in order to separate them into simpler things, wich the brain does all the time. Perhaps the concept of life is irrelevant to the appreciation of what we call our lives, and feeling alive. What we call our lives is in fact consciousness. So the better question is what is consciousness? And are computers viruses conscious? And how the hell can we ever know but ask them? But what if we can't communicate with them? What if the only way to fgure out if something is conscious is to see if it reacts to our presence? All valid questions.

'What if we could never get the answer?' is also something we have to consider.

I'm a little bit bothered by your terminology. You keep using the term "dead" for things like viruses, molecules, and rocks, however, "dead" implies that the object it is the adjective to used to be alive. Viruses, molecules and rocks did never transit to their current state from being alive, as such, they could never have died and cannot be dead. They are lifeless, not currently alive and also not previousely alive, a.k.a. dead. Now, technically, you could apply the term "dead" to certain types of sediment rock, such as coal or chalk, which are composed of compressed dead organic mass (trees and crustaceans, respectively), though that would be like referring to your own feces as dead, as it is made up of the remains of dead stuff. Mostly we do not do that, as there has been another transit between the dead stuff and its current state, ergo dead stuff can turn into lifeless stuff.

In the last 200,000 years of evolution we development of complex brains with capacity for language, tool making, art, culture, and the written language.  We can only imagine the evolutionary process technology will go through in a fraction of that time.  However, its only after this happens will technology also be able to teach us how limiting our brains are.  The way in witch we figure that out (through extinction,  or transcendence) isn't clear since we don't have a deep enough understanding of life to accurately theorize how it will behave artificial.

This is a really muddled question. The term 'life' can have many different meanings. When we talk about life we usually know the context of what we are referring to as life. There is no confusion when you say someone is alive or dead. There's no confusion when you say a cell is alive or dead. It's the context that matters. (And let's not get into a debate about nearly dead or nearly alive.) The argument that this is skirting around is the definition of consciousness.

Frankly, I understand the arguments but I find them unimaginative--just plain dull. There's nothing new or unique to these questions. I suspect the person who came-up with this theory thought they were clever with what is nothing more than a hand full of philosophical questions. Yawn.

I believe that AI is actual life. Why you ask_ Well little child, let me explain. We know that the brain is part of our body that "holds" our consciousness. We know this, becasue we can lose limbs, adn still have no problem with staying conscious. If we wanted to, we could, with extremely fine technology, remove the brain from a human, and put it into a machine with different sensors that act as senses. I don't know how that would feel, but theoretically it should work. But here's a twist: We are the brain, but people have suffered different kinds of brain damage, and live. Lets say we combined every brain damage ever recorded, where the sufferer still survives. This would brobably include the entire brain. Which means that there is no specific point in the brain that is "us". And brain cells die and switch all the time, but we don't lack "life" because of that. We aren't the cells of the brain. We are the pulses. You know the small electrical charges thart basically power our brain? That is what we are. Which means that a, lets say, a circuit board with a program that runs an AI, should be alive as well, because it is powered by electrical charges.

Life is the chemical reaction between complex molecules, which create  cells, which create tissues, which create organs, which create systems, which create life.  Usually, when people say life, they mean the operation of people, walking, talking, having a personality, etc.  However, these are just effects of chemical reactions, nothing more.  Cells have protective caps on them (I forget their names), which degrade over time.  You lose about 75 million cells a day, which your body is constantly reproducing.  Over time, this process slows down, until it stops completely.  This is death.  Life is just a chain of chemical reactions, nothing more.

Thing is, our currently perceived universe is created by our minds. Our senses and minds are the final filter of reality to our consciousness. Right now, the universe if simply our consciousness. We cannot observe anything outside of our human perspective of, everything. It's like we're in school and somehow we're locked in the math room with no previous learning of other subjects. We can learn a lot about math, but cannot begin to even guess what the other subjects are like, let alone know significant information about them. The best we have is guesses. One person in the math room could somehow, randomly guess cell theory, but without access to the whole School, and the science room no one can say anything about it. At that point, any guess to anything scientific with no previous/current and future knowledge could be considered better than cell theory. With this analogy, I think that the only subjects unlocked are the subjects created based on human function and interaction.

Well, I know only the basics of various scientifc research, but |I did spend a few years studying philosophy. Artguably you could merely look at life as complexity. Or more correctly, when does stuff stop being stuff and begins to operate in a way and manner that wouldn't occur if you merely collected the perfect amount of every type of matter that went into that thing, and merely compressed it all together and observes what happens. Or you can look at it as the Little Gods method ... when does an organism start/stop (living/dead) recognising itself as if beyond merely the base material components of its parts? In essence, when does a cell stop recognising other cells compared with simply inert matter?


Recognition of self and other is traditionally something associated with all living things. And ultimately that is the universe recognising itself as both self and other. A duality of being alive is being the universe and knowing of the universe. When that is no longer happening, we are for all intents and purposes very dead. This definition works to exclude things like, as you said before, automated goop ... whilst allowing for things like eukaryotes. It also allows us to make moral judgements of 'dead' when we apply this to the exacting degree of sentience of higher animals.

Well, existence is narration - information put in an order (at least by the appearance of time). To gain insight into the order of existence, it is very fruitful to look into complex and modern analysis of narration (my advice is Gerard Genettes "The Narration"). In this understanding every new way to put order into information is a bubble, that gets shifted into existence/narration (Genette calls that "extradiegetic act"). That doesn't mean that one bubble stops being active, after the next one is becoming active. They interact further. You would have to put it into this order chronologically: Raw laws of physics in the first moment (although "moment" transports a semantic picture that seems to postulate a timeline that is too long), then cemics, then after a long time biology, then feeling (neurological processes), then language (in signs between complexer beings), then consciesness, then spoken language (although it might be the other way around), then written words and numbers, then binarecodes put in action, then maybe AI. But that doesn't bring up an explanation what is alive and what isn't. To give an answer to this questions, I refer to a theory about media, that I came upon in an university course and then mixed up with a metaphor from a philosophical book called "Die Geniereligion": Static is death, dynamic is life. In this understanding we actually live on, after our consciousness is dead. By the impression we left within other people, by ideas we visited and made acceptable for other people, and maybe also by sharing part of our genetic Information to give birth to a new offspring. And even, when the information we came up with, isn't dynamic anymore, but static, the information that we have been is the dead matter the dynamic layer is active upon. In this regard (and here comes the metaphor) life can be very well depicted as wood in it's living form. A tree is only partially alive. The wood that once was alive is present as bark and by itself part of the organism. Although evenutally, one day, all life in the universe will end, be it by a great rift or just by getting cold and using up all of it's energy, the information that we have been, just like the universe will go on forever. It might seems odd, but this gives me redemption...

Life like any other word is just a grouping of ideas made into one term so we can address it. In the scientific world, in order to call something alive or dead it must meet a list of criterion. Things can meet most of, but not all of these criterion and may even appear undeniably alive, but we do not call them so. If by life you mean consciousness then one should take into account where the consciousness is created, in the brain. We know that brains work very much like computers, they intake patterns and react accordingly based on the structure they were "turned on with". Consciousness, while we may not know exactly where it is created in the brain, is just the ability of a pattern, to recognize itself, and incorporate that knowledge into its processes.
None of this is by any means simple in its execution but conceptually it's not "rocket science", it is in fact Biology. ;D

Even the wall between wakefulness and sleep is enormously complex and mysterious let alone the wall between life and death.

Life is essentially a mathematical oddity in a universe that flows in a different direction. An equation that replicates itself and increases its own order at the expense of increasing the disorder of its surroundings.

This can be replicated in relatively simple computer simulations. Self replicating units, that take resources, convert them into their own building blocks, then reproduce. If the replication process is prone to slight errors, even evolution of the self replicating units can be observed.

While it may ultimately be futile or pointless, if the universe is to suffer a big rip or heat death, anything that's capable of resisting the increase of disorder of its own components, necessarily at the expense of the disorder of its surroundings, is alive.

Consciousness is a different thing and i think many people confuse it with life. The complexity of my body gives rise to my consciousness which allows me to experience the universe, when I die it is lost forever but the matter that made stays here and loses its ability to work against entropy.

I know a lot of people would deny the existence of consciousness as a "ghost in the machine", illusion, theological creation or unscientific, but the problem is.... is that it can't be observed by science. For instance, just say I have a thought about what I did the other day, something like, "What did I have to study for school yesterday", the scientist would say that this is reducible to the CNS and endocrine systems but this is just not true. You can not deny that the content was there, in some way or another I had the thought, "What did I have to study for school yesterday", and it was apparent to me in my experience. Therefore, there is some state of existence in which the qualia of our experience is present, but science can not discover.

In short, I find it highly unscientific for science to dismiss logical states of existence because of an assumption, an assumption that the existence of cause and effect, is the only state of existence.

Kind of interesting but also quite irrelevant. The concept of life and death is easily understood in everyday speech, putting an exact definition on it doesn't really offer much benefit. Also it's meaning differs depending on the context.

As far as AI goes, we already have that in a way. We have cars that can park themselves, smartphones that can listen to us and respond with basic intelligence, search engines that try to understand and predict what we mean. The difference between that and most people's concept of AI is that they don't think for themselves, they might seem intelligent but are actually following pre-programmed routines.

But if that's your definition of AI - something that can think for itself rather than following pre-programmed routines, you have to ask what's the point?

I'm pretty sure AI would be quite easy to write programatically, I came up with some algorithms that should do it (based on analysing how my own brain works). The problem is it'd be very costly in both time and money to implement, and to what end? What's the point of writing a program/computer than can think for itself? The whole point of computers is that they do what we tell them to do. They're kind of like slaves that we don't have to feel guilty about because they have no feelings. They don't have their own agenda, their own purpose, their own wants. We built them to do what we tell them. The only way you can ultimately get something to truly "think for itself" is to give it some kind of motivation. A complex internal system of motivations could be described as artificial feelings/emotions, which would raise moral ambiguity as to whether it itself is alive and whether it deserves human rights like we do. You could question what are our own emotions other than electrical signals whizzing around inside our brain? How would that be different to a computer? We built computers to benefit ourselves not itself, and the only way to get it to truly think for itself would mean the latter. You could try to make that mutually beneficial for example enjoying doing cleaning and laundry like Kryten of Red Dwarf, it might work but you're still opening a pretty dangerous can of worms.

At the end of the day if you want true intelligence, have a baby or buy a dog! Leave computers the way they are - designed to do exactly what we tell them to do!

The problem is only definition.
Life is not a precise definition and then you can extent it to what the criteria is for life.
The question is more when is something biological. Everything is made up from matter, which is dead. Then when occurrences happens, which makes the dead matter react, then comes potential for a repeating pattern of processes, which makes cells/ or others.
Then when cells becomes clusters which can be any biological being we have, that is when it is considered to be alive.
But then again we are back at the definition of alive. Does the matter have to be conscious? Does it only need to operate? and so on.
And as the example in the video show, processes of matter can manifest in many different forms, which is not the one we are build of.
If we break our body down, we are essential "machines" with a certain interval of capabilities. This could for an instance suggest that an A.I. with enough capability could be considered alive( having conciousness), but this A.I., would work under different properties, than the common conception of life does( being born, reproducing, dying).
If the scenario was here what would the A.I. call itself? And if it had a different opinion, would it still be taking in to account?

And all these question all ends back at definition. If the definition for life is that the being has to be capable of dying, then other definitions will be placed for those sentience beings which cannot. And then it becomes an ethical question, which is always just opinions.

HOW THE FUCK DOES THIS HELP MY ANXIETY?

I must first start off by confessing my weakness as it relates to my scientifical knowledge of matter. You appear to be pretty studied or at least have a keen sense of some of these things. So, I would like to respond in a way that may NOT address every issue you raised, not because I disregard it or didn't thoroughly consider your thoughts but because I think that if we address the "meaning of life" over all, then it actually brings greater light to smaller questions. In other words, if we where to see a tool box filled with tools then, sure, we could discuss how to operate each one of them. But when you know the project that is being built, each individual tool now takes on a greater meaning or at least gives clarity to better understanding its individual use, purpose, and value. Also, before I get started, let's establish that there is indeed Absolute Truth. Anyone who disagrees would cut off the very branch they are sitting on. I'm sure you've heard the old story of the guy who asks, "Is there absolute truth?" The man listening responds, "Of course, not! We can be sure about nothing!" To which the questioner replies, "Are you sure about that?" I'm sure you will agree that truth does exist. If it had not, there would be no point in us seeking it out.

With that said, let me cut right to the throat by answering the question: Why is there life?

(Of course, as you may have assumed, all my answers will be from scripture (The Bible). So, I do not proclaim to know all things. But I do proclaim that the scriptures are infact the TRUTH and thus reveal something about all things. If they did not, then like any rational mind, I would discount them altogether.)


Isaiah 43:5 says about man,

5Do not be afraid, for I am with you;
I will bring your children from the east
and gather you from the west.
6I will say to the north, ‘Give them up!’
and to the south, ‘Do not hold them back.’
Bring my sons from afar
and my daughters from the ends of the earth—
7everyone who is called by my name,
whom I created for my glory,
whom I formed and made.”


Psalm 19 says about creation:

1The heavens declare the glory of God;
the skies proclaim the work of his hands.
2Day after day they pour forth speech;
night after night they reveal knowledge.
3They have no speech, they use no words;
no sound is heard from them.
4Yet their voiceb goes out into all the earth,
their words to the ends of the world.
In the heavens God has pitched a tent for the sun.
5It is like a bridegroom coming out of his chamber,
like a champion rejoicing to run his course.
6It rises at one end of the heavens
and makes its circuit to the other;
nothing is deprived of its warmth.


So, there it is, all of CREATION, far and near, living and inanimate, was made to spread the knowledge of God. Habakuk 2 says,

"For the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the Lord
as the waters cover the sea."

Notice it says KNOWLEDGE OF THE GLORY OF GOD. Not because by knowledge we understand all things, but because our knowledge (tho limited) of all things helps us to understand HIS GLORY.

So, the bible clearly says God made all things for HIS GLORY. The meaning of our existence is to glorify God. If we conclude this then we don't arragantly assume to know everything. But we do conclude to know something about everything. Let me demonstrate this in a couple thoughts:

Q: Why is the universe so huge?
A: The scriptures above give much clarity to this question. The universe was created to spread the knowledge of God's Glory. This would explain why such a huge universe. God is in a sence saying, "Behold my power!".

Tho, this answer is simple, in-fact I will admit, too simple. The irony is that without this answer nothing makes sense as it relates to the finality of all things. Yet, with this answer, altho not everything is known, something is known about everything!'

Here is another:
Q:Why do people strive to live moral lives?
If the answer is, "to spread the Glory of God ", then there is a great deal of sense to a man's striving to live moral. Yet, if a man does not believe in God and yet seeks to live morally still, then there is no real sense of finality to his cause. He may say he does not want to hurt others. But why? He surly can not say "it's not nice to". If he does, then he must define why he has a sense of what's nice and what's not? He can't say that it is a natural instinct because if he does then he runs into a problem. When he strives to live "nice" then he reveals that he has another instinct within him striving against his initial will also. That is a natural instinct of NOT doing what's "nice". Now, if both of these are natural instincts built into the frame of man by way of evolution then how does he determine which one is most beneficial? I assume he would say the one that works to further the existence of man. And here lies the problem: If there is no absolute reason for man to exist then why is there such an impulse to see to it that he does?
I think that our life is a scientific experiment. And the best results will be used in more complex compounds.

My personal belief in what constitutes as life is any assortment of matter that obtains and gathers a source of energy for the sake of self replicating some intrinsic information.

By that definition, a virus is not life because it does not have its own metabolism. A computer virus is not life because its source of power is external and beyond its own ability to obtain that energy.

There's also something called transposons. It's a segment of DNA that serves no role in the success of the organism. It's only purpose is to propagate its own existence. It replicates itself and then relocates somewhere else in the DNA. Its existence is not that unlike a virus.

My thought is that "life" is just animated goo of varying complexities, yes, but the real important topic is consciousness. Without brains we're all just collections of cells, like jellyfish with no central nervous system. Cells, jellyfish, bacteria, plants, all of them are clearly just a collection of organs at best. Once you add a brain there's something different, and I would guess that consciousness is not something you can truly program, transfer, or upload. I have no idea why it would be that way, and I'm open to being proven wrong, but so far that simply seems to be the case.

Claiming that technology is "close" is a little misleading when there's clearly something absolutely missing from AI. Even neural nets are just working like brain cells at best. They remember like a brain does, but they don't think.

Sorry this comment is really long, but it REALLY made me think:

One similarity I notice between us and bacteria is that we need to keep breeding to stay alive. Bacteria kept breeding for whatever reason, and we do the same thing. Since we (distantly) evolved from bacteria, are we motivated to breed because bacteria did? Sure, our brain cells are much larger than theirs (some if them don't even have brains), but a lot of it was used for instinct and keeping us alive. For example, our eyesight is much better than many other species, because we rely on it. Bacteria is a little like this, but on the smaller, microscopic scale. They're mostly singular cells, that then evolved into several cells. An average human body is made up of 100 trillion cells, to be approximate. So what if we're just giant bacteria? Survive, breed; These instincts impact us. If we didn't breed, why would we even need to feel pain in the first place? This is why I believe we regret to die and other's to die. When you form a bond with someone, it makes you feel like they're semi-family. Someone dying means they can't make more young, and can't care for them if they do have some, so that they can do the same. In fact, a lot of our brain functions slightly revolve around this, although I will admit that a lot of isn't so. It's almost as if we live to breed. And so does bacteria. Does bacteria or something that came before it know something we don't? In this case, are we just giant bacteria? It's unsolvable to us. In I-don't-know-how-long, will we be bacteria in comparison to something else? Is there something below bacteria that we can't see?
I think the most perplexing question next to what is life, is what does it mean to have consciousness? Will our "souls" for lack of a better term, be infinite? Or is this our only shot at life?

I have always thought of alive as being things which actively respond to some stimuli. So I consider a rock to be not alive because though it can be broken or incinerated it does not have an active role in that response to the stimuli. However the way cells respond to stimuli is really just a more sophisticated version of a forced reaction like incineration or separation. So perhaps an additional feature needs to be the ability to die, the capability to reach a point of no longer be able to perform active reactions. A rock will always be able to react the same way to stimuli so long as it is not destroyed, but I will someday loose the vast majority of my responses to stimuli being left with only the same ones as the rock (with the addition of rotting). Perhaps then the true definition of being alive is the capacity to die.

After closely reviewing every one of your lovely videos, I've only found three errors worth commenting on.  This is my third comment of three (the other two are on the pro-nuclear video and the big bang video).

The main problem I have with the script for this video is that you're missing the larger point: science is no longer essentialistic.  Let me explain.

A bit more than a century ago, biologists actually used to argue over what the term "life" should mean, as though its definition were of central importance to the discipline.  But today, biologists don't argue with each other in the manner suggested in this video.

So... what happened?  Why did the outlook change, and how do we see things now?

Science underwent a number of bold paradigmatic shifts in the late 1800's.  One of these was a movement from the scholastic model (where science was about debating the meanings of things said by older authorities) to the academic model (where science is now about challenging old precepts and seeing what survives assault).  But there was perhaps an even larger philosophical shift: science stopped being essentialistic and started being operationistic.  This shift deepened even further in the mid 1900's with the discovery of statistical methods which allowed the birth of the scientific study of social phenomena.

Essentialism is the old idea that the words we use are attempts to model some critical underlying concept.  In order to understand the world, we need to carefully define our terms so that each term matches the underlying idea properly.  By this view, the definition of "life" is of supreme importance: there is some "life" delineation and we can't truly understand it unless we bound it properly, through investigation and tons of debate.  The assumption here is that our languages mirror in some way a deeper reality, and if you think about it you might start to see where that idea goes wrong.

Operationism is the way science actually works today.  You may have heard that in science, all definitions are operational definitions.  What does that mean?  It means each definition is tied to a measurement of one form or another: what we claim to know, we have to know through empirical connection to the universe around us (or with "pure" science like mathematical sciences, by empirical study of logic and theory itself, to see the results of particular deterministic structural choices).

Put another way, scientists today don't care what a term "means", because we realize the terminology we use does not define truth.  The only reason we use terms in science is so that we can communicate without ambiguity.  It doesn't matter what we define "life" to be. We simply use whichever definition is most convenient to the study of biological processes, and that definition may change over time.  But changing the definition of life doesn't change reality.  It's just a word; a tool for communication.

So scientists don't actually argue over things in this way, and the "what is life" question is deceptively unscientific.  It's a trap we used to fall into 150 years ago, but we don't anymore.

All that said, there is an interesting question that I think you're starting to get at, but it isn't about life: it's about consciousness, the patterns from which it arises, and the extent to which it is or is not present in things.  But that is a much larger topic than can be covered in a kurzgesagt (and why I'm currently writing a book).

Alright everybody, new details are in. The verdict is that all of the scientific theories about the beginning of the universe are all wrong.
Theory 1: "The universe was created by gravity." Wrong, in order for gravity to create the universe it would have to be eternal which it isn't.
Theory 2: "The Big Bang began the universe." Wrong, according to the big bang theory, the universe began by expanding from an infinitesimal volume with extremely high density and temperature. The universe was initially significantly smaller than even a pore on your skin. With the big bang, the fabric of space itself began expanding like the surface of an inflating balloon-matter simply rode along the stretching space like dust on the balloon's surface. The big bang is not like an explosion of matter in otherwise empty space; rather, space itsself began with the big bang and carried matter with it as it expanded. But this theory only tells us what happened immediately after-not at or before the singularity. That's all the math can explain.
Theory 3: "The Laws of Physics Began the Universe." Wrong, science says the reason why our universe exists is because of the Laws of Physics. But can't exactly explain how or why. And since nothing is eternal, then what created the Laws of Physics? Here's what I say, if there's nothing there then nothing can come out of it. So, whatever was present before the beginning has to be eternal otherwise it couldn't possibly exist.

If you want a quick answer to this question, life is basically just any collection of atoms that meet the (7) criteria listed in the video (and here: http://infohost.nmt.edu/~klathrop/7characterisitcs_of_life.htm). But if you're looking for a more philosophical answer, than it depends entirely on your own beliefs and opinions. At any scale, what entity you consider dead or alive could be completely different from the person next to you. If you were shown an atom, would you consider it alive? How about if you were told that the atom exists in a living human? And don't forget about the millions of electrons being manipulated inside the neural web-work of your nervous system, should those electrons be considered alive as well? Unlike most aspects of the definite world of science, the debate of 'dead or alive' is (within reason) open to interpretation.

“We are going to die, and that makes us the lucky ones. Most people are never going to die because they are never going to be born. The potential people who could have been here in my place but who will in fact never see the light of day outnumber the sand grains of Arabia. Certainly those unborn ghosts include greater poets than Keats, scientists greater than Newton. We know this because the set of possible people allowed by our DNA so massively exceeds the set of actual people. In the teeth of these stupefying odds it is you and I, in our ordinariness, that are here.We privileged few, who won the lottery of birth against all odds, how dare we whine at our inevitable return to that prior state from which the vast majority have never stirred?”

- Richard Dawkins
