Well, here is my understanding of life...
Please make sure you read it to the end and then react.Thanks :)
So I believe its like a prison. You are caged here. No way out. I know it sounds sad but wait it gets better as I go on.
We believe, every living thing on earth has a soul. That is how they are differentiated from non living things like rocks and sand etc. Who made souls? Well, we believe God made souls. What (who) is god? We don't know. No one has ever seen it(him/her/they/them/whatever). We only just assume, or we WANT to assume. Every single day since your childhood you have been taught that life is beautiful, its wonderful, mysterious, fun. You started believing that. You think life is beautiful, we are lucky to be here, we are happy. But what if its not like that, what if you were misled? You know it, you have experienced it. Life is full of suffering. Its unfair. Its cruel. Its unforgiving.
Earth is like a giant prison. And we are prisoners here. From birth to death you are supposed to do only one thing without failing, be alive ! At all costs ! You are made this way. Your body is made this way. Your body doesn't care about fun. It doesn't care about money. Its only job is to keep you alive. At any cost. Someone (God...may be?) wants you to be alive here. Wants you to live through it.
Why is there so much suffering? Why is world never peaceful? Why are we not equal? Why someone enjoys a good life, while someone lives in sorrow? Why is there crime?
Why always good people suffer?
The only answer to this never ending list of questions is, someone wants the world to function this way.
You are not supposed to be at peace here. Even though you feel like you are happy, you are not ! No one can be happy all of his life. Some suffer now, some will later.
If 'God' wanted you to be happy here, why would he even invent pain or suffering? Doesn't it seem illogical? Why would he create this complex world? Wouldn't he keep it nice and simple? If he only wanted you to come here and experience his beautiful creation and be a part of it, he would do so without all the complications. It would be a world with peace, happiness and no one will suffer, no one will fight, everyone will love each other and it would come from inside our mind(brain), as he who made us would have made us to be that way.
Obviously, he didn't ! but why?
Because in my understanding we are sent here to serve a sentence. What if there is an another universe? What if we were part of that universe, and are sent here because of our deeds? What if we are actually in HELL right now?
Maybe I am wrong. Who knows? But what if I'm right???
Our mind is not supposed to ask these questions, yet I'm still asking? Maybe I was supposed to think this way. Maybe you think I am depressed, you would ask me to get a life, you will ignore me, you will make fun out of me. But that doesn't answer the questions. May be I am depressed, but why am I depressed? Again it is only he who made me invented this disorder, didn't he? May be he wanted me to think about it, increase my distress? If he didn't want me to think this way, my mind would never do so.
Why don't all of us think over it that much? Because we made ourselves engaged elsewhere, to avoid such thoughts. We have been doing that since the start I guess.
Faith, Culture, Society, Events, Festivals, School, Work the list goes on...
Only to keep you away from the grips of your mind. We made ourselves so busy, we never ask the most trivial question, WHAT ARE WE DOING HERE?
Why do most of us tend to ignore this question? An act of kindness maybe? by those who sent us here? to create our minds to not question it?
Some of us sip on coffee while browsing internet on their iPhones. While there are people who don't have drinking water.
Some of us have thousands of dollars while there are people who eat stale bread from a trash can in order to be alive? What do you call this? Fate?
I call it judgement.  
Diseases, Wars, Terrorism, Racism... why are these negative factors present? To keep you suffering maybe? Every year a new disease breaks out.How come? Where do these viruses come from suddenly?
We consider ourselves, the most intelligent. The human. Proud and strong. Dominated the entire world with his intelligence. Our brain is the most developed among all the animals. Why? Ever asked this question to yourself? Why are we so intelligent? What is the purpose of having such an advanced brain? I guess not. No one knows. No one wants to know.
Some of us are tall, some of us short, some of us beautiful, some of us not that much (I wont use the word ugly), some of us brave, some of us not much, some are favourites, some are neglected, some cool, some mundane. What do you call this? Genes?
I call it judgement.
Maybe I'm wrong. Who knows? but what if I'm right??
On an average, a human lives for about 70 years. Why 70? why limited? like a sentence may be? serving for a lifetime? for 70 years. Some are released before, some are held. Its ironic how it resembles our own prison system.
Its funny how we have borders for our nations, like bars in prison, separating inmates to avoid fights. Well, we have borders to avoid fights. This is yours, this is mine. Not our fault though, we are made this way. Even animals fight for their territory.
Ever wondered why are we the only ones in the universe? Why is there no planet like earth close to us. Like in our own solar system. Why do we have to search millions and millions of miles for a sign of life? We haven't discovered any planet that is equivalent to earth in its characteristics. If we were to discover life outside earth, wouldn't 'they' place it nearby? What if they don't want us to discover life, or in fact there is no life outside at all? Or maybe there is. Who knows? Aliens, extra terrestrials, UFOs. No one has proof. Only claims. 
I'm in my early adulthood and I have so many questions about life that no one seems to be interested about. Maybe they don't have answers, maybe they don't want answers, maybe they are too busy to find answers, or just too scared? Who knows?
I do not claim to be right. I do not insist you to agree. I just present my opinion. May be I am wrong. Who knows? but what if I am right...
Like if you can, so that more people can see it, and I might be able to get close to getting  answers. Because its not the likes that I'm after, its the answer.

Sorry to burst your bubble there but we are no where near artificial intelligence. Every last man made machine that we have function with a very simple principle, that is that they are simple mindless chains of events set up by humans. Let me explain.

Imagine the mouse trap and the inner working of a clock. In a mouse trap, a mouse gives the trap an input by triggering the release mechanism, thus releasing the snap bar. You wouldn't call the trap intelligent because it killed the mouse. In a clock, one gear turns another and another, and what we see is the time. You wouldn't call the clock intelligent because it knows the time. Both of these machines function on very simple designed functions that are set up, NOT by the capacity of their own intelligence.

Now imagine artificial intelligence. Some people might confuse, say Siri, for artificial intelligence because she acts like a human. That is where they are wrong. When she receives a "hello", she would greet back, but by no capacity of her own intelligent design but instead a predetermined result, set by her designers. Even if Apple was so careful as to include EVERY possible conversation into Siri's program, she would still be nothing but a mindless collection of predetermined results. All of our AI are no different, they are simple well designed sets of mindless collections of information.

For the entire history of mankind since the beginning of our existence, our machines have not progressed and deviated from this simple mechanism. Despite all of our scientific advancements, there has never, ever, been one time that mankind's machines operated outside of their set functions, that is, a mouse trap has never been able to control its own actions, just as Siri is not able to control her own actions. The simple machine that is a mouse trap is not so different from the billion dollar AI that thousands of our finest scientists are working on right now.

La Vida no es esencialmente diferente al resto de la naturaleza, pero se distingue por ser una forma altamente organizada de materia orgánica que ha desarrollado cualidades especiales.

La Vida es un movimiento unitario y no puede ser comprendida solo a través de sus partes, fragmentarla es negarla; Es la relación que han establecido todas las partículas que la constituyen lo que la hace posible; Cuando esa relación cesa, la Vida se desintegra.

El fin de la Vida no es meramente reproducirse para garantizar su sobre-vivencia y traspasar información genética; Es adoptar nuevas formas de ser, es concebir nuevas realidades, es establecer nuevas relaciones, es conocerse y perfeccionarse a si misma, es seguir aprendiendo y disfrutando de la existencia.

La única diferencia que veo entre la Vida y la tecnología es que la Vida puede conocerse y maravillarse de si misma y del mundo que le rodea, y aunque se configure a una maquina para que sea ignorante de si misma y del mundo simplemente no poseerá esa veradera inocencia.

La Humanidad no es superior las demás formas de Vida, cada forma ha evolucionado de acuerdo a sus necesidades; Es la idea de ser superiores al resto lo que ha degradado nuestra relación con los demás seres vivientes; Sin embargo, la Humanidad posee capacidades especiales que le han permitido transformar a la Tierra como ninguna otra forma de Vida puede; Pero ese poder no le da el derecho de violentarla y dominarla, sino que le da la responsabilidad de protegerla y mejorarla.

Definir a la Vida es dejar de conocerla, e imitarla con maquinas es desperdiciar energía que podría ser invertida en su preservación y comprensión.

Life is an emergent property of non-living matter, just as awareness is an emergent property of the activity of neurons, or the shape of a snowflake is an emergent property of hydrogen bonding between water molecules.  To claim that something isn't alive because its component parts aren't alive is a composition fallacy.  It's like claiming that a pile of sand can't exist because a grain of sand isn't a pile.

The confusion about what is or isn't alive is a case of trying to fit things into boxes, finding that some things don't fit neatly, and blaming the things when the boxes are the problem.

"matter of complexity". Well said.

Wherever distinctions are drawn, some degree of truth is lost. "Life" isn't something separate from the rest of the inanimate universe: if we liken everything that exists to lego pieces, life is nothing more than a specific arrangement of lego pieces that produces certain functions.

Life has no absolute purpose, but we as living things are free to create relative ones. It's as if lego pieces met together and came to life then asked why they exist. It's absurd, it's cowardly, it's pointless--life preserves itself for no real reason (not reproduction, biological reasons don't make sense if we keep questioning it).

We were the inanimate universe, then that primordial ooze, we were the burning stars that formed the planets and systems: when life first appeared it acquired an ego, and with the feeling of "self" it forgot what it was. We were "everything" before the big bang, all things that existed in a singularity, then in a relative universe we separated into distinct things yet all composed of the same stuff... it's all an experience--the singular universe experiencing itself through a myriad of different iterations and possibilities. Life is just another consequence of the physical laws that rule our world. In the same way water tends to flow downstream due to gravity or evaporates due to heat forming a cycle, what we call life is just the trend followed by very complex sets of molecules during millions of years, from very simple forms of living to very complex ones, due to what we call evolution. There's not a transcendental or supranatural reason for life, it is just the way atoms behave forming sets when they follow the physical laws of the universe for billions of years in certain conditions.

I do maintain, however, that the scientific definition of life is mechanistic and tends to invalidate philosophy as a whole--every question about life and its metaphysical implications are thrown to the dogs, because everything is ultimately the product of chemical processes, and that's the end of it. Firstly, it occur to me that there's a logic error at the end, where it was said that since all matter regardless of being alive or dead are all made up of fundamental particles, therefore everything has to be either all dead or all alive.
Well for me, identity means sameness in all physical categories, or at least similar enough to not differentiable.
For example a piece of graphite is distinctive different from a piece of diamond even though essentially both are made up of Carbon, and reasonably so, we don't hear people say: "Since both graphite and diamond are made up of Carbon, therefore either all graphite is diamond, or all diamond is graphite". Like for determining whether something is alive or dead, having to say that they are both made up of fundamental particles is too wide of a scope, that's like saying because both you and I are on Earth, therefore we are at the same place in spacetime.
Both me and a rock can have the exact same make-up, but because the arrangement of the particles and energy state of those particles and the chemical reactions of those particles in my body are vastly or even totally different from a rock, therefore there's a difference between me and a rock. Having 1 similar properties does not make 2 objects with multiple properties identical.

Secondly, the logic of "we can't define the difference, therefore there's no difference", doesn't seem to run well. It could be due to the flaw of our language, or that the human brain is not good enough to define such complex terms such as life and death, but that does not mean fundamentally there is no physical difference between living things and non-living things. Even if we can't draw a definite line on morality and immorality, that doesn't mean that the act of Hitler's Holocaust is as moral as a man who sacrifice his own life to protect save the world. Not having the ability to definitively differentiate moral acts from immoral acts does not necessarily entail that the behaviors can be spoken of on the same plane. Not having the ability to definitively differentiate the living and the dead does not necessarily entail that the two properties can be spoken of interchangeably.

Of course there's a difference between living and non-living things. Here is the rough argument that the video gives:

1. Every molecule of an animal is non-living.
2. Therefore, animals are non-living.

But that is fallacious reasoning. Premise 2 doesn't follow from premise 1. In fact, it's such a common mistake that there's a name for it--the fallacy of composition. Here's an example of the same form of reasoning:

1. Every molecule of an animal is colorless.
2. Therefore, animals are colorless.

Just because all of a things parts has some property that doesn't mean that the whole object must have that property, too.

In order to define life or distinguish living things from things that aren't alive, you have to first establish some ontological categories and decide whether you accept or do not accept an exclusively sense data based basis for reality. As either accepting or rejecting an ontological basis for existence, on what can be measured or not, is a decision that can neither be proven or disproven, it will provide an intellectually equal and arbitrary assumption from which to build other categories of existence, from the most basic (e.g. spatial spread and motion) to the most complex (e.g. complex self awareness and rational abstraction).

It will also dramatically influence the interpretive world-view and bias with which you proceed. The above little film builds to an increasingly diluted and ambiguous notion of life by employing an extremely reductive, positivist set of assumptions and interpretive bias to extrapolate a hardboiled empiricists worldview, all the time assuming that there is no other standpoint from which to build an interpretive model while lapsing into intellectually disingenuous absolutes about the theoretical framework it is using. Chill out people - we don't know. We (ALL of us) join the dots and fill in the blanks according to what ever world view we espouse, ALL of which necessarily (by virtue of our inherently finite and inescapably limited scope of experience and reference) are necessarily and inescapably metaphysical (i.e. beyond empirical scope or enquiry). 

Choose your paradigm and extrapolate accordingly but don't kid yourself that you know. They don't either. No one does.

Believing the difference between artificial and organic intelligence is merely quantitative (i.e. believing that there is no difference in quality and, therefore, it is just a matter of time until technology is able to build a fully conscious machine) is actually an act of faith from neopositivists – the arguments are never convincing (e.g. "there is a lot of intelligent people working on that"). We have been able so far to build a machine so sophisticated that it can even compete and win on Jeopardy against the best competitors ever (IBM's Watson), but there is one big difference: the machine doesn't have the slightest idea of what it's actually doing, it operates strictly with logic and statistics. Consciousness is not an algorithm, thinking is not an entirely formal activity. There are always emotional, proprioceptive (body-aware) components involved. Our experience of life isn't entirely dependent on our brains, we have an extremely complex body too and one cannot live apart from the other. In sum, we are a complex system and there is a dialectical relationship between the parts and the whole that cannot be emulated by the analytical procedure of decomposing the parts until we reach a single most fundamental element; in fact, everything matters. That's why calling a cell a tiny machine isn't actually accurate, in my opinion. I don't mean, by that, that we will never be able to fully replicate consciousness starting from lifeless matter (cloning doesn't help here, since we are not going from lifeless matter to a living thing), but surely there is something missing in our equation. Maybe vitalists are not entirely wrong after all.

This whole video is just debating the definition of a word. Life as we use the word would be a combination of all the things that make us alive. The reactions, the DNA, etc. When these things are combined then we have life. When these things create a complex system known as an advanced brain, then we have intelligent life.

Very educational video nonetheless. I agree that we use the word 'life' as if it is some magical way in which we animate and operate when really it is just DNA, chemical reactions, cells, etc. that keep us going.

I think "life" is an emergent property that arises from a complex system, much like how cars can only run properly when all the components are together in the right way. Since there are many ways to arrange a system into configurations that can be "alive", it is very difficult to rigorously define life. Hence I think defining life based on the life we find on Earth could lead to some wrong deductions. 
For example, are sterile animals (such as mules) dead because they can't reproduce? Perhaps reproduction is not a fundamental property of life, but rather a property required for its propagation?
It is obvious that an organism must have a way to continue its existence for it to be observed, which is why all the organisms we observe have this capability (reproduction). But this can also be achieved by being immortal (or being very long-lived). If you think about it, you can even say that that a lineage of organisms is just a single system that has been spatiotemporally separated, and that "reproduction" is just another form of "immortality".
This fits nicely with Schrodinger's definition of life, which I think is the best way to define life without getting cluttered up in details that might not even be relevant.


Another opinion I have is that  being subject to evolution is only a consequence of having certain reproductive properties (e.g. heredity, variation etc), and so should not be part of the definition.

This is a great example of why reductionism isn't the sole way to get to the bottom of understanding something as interesting as life. I feel like there is a lot of this type of thinking when we approach the problem of understanding consciousness. We reduce and reduce and it becomes less and less comprehensible.

We need to strike a balance between understanding the small components and looking at the big picture the video closes with. Neither extreme will provide understanding. In all things we need to find a balance... a "middle way."

This is starting to sound like "is a bag containing chocolate, flour, eggs, baking powder, and water a cake?"

Life as an experience is the result of the orderly behavior of many "dead" things. The way that these dead things interact is causally linked to life as an experience. Stop drinking water for more than a couple of days, and you're dead. Have a fructose absorption disorder, and you are very likely to also have a tryptophan uptake disorder, which will ultimately lead to decreased brain activity and is one way by which people become clinically depressed. Tryptophan is a dead thing. It is an amino acid, not a "living thing." It does not experience all the chemical reactions that render us able to interact with the environment the way we living things do. Yet it is turned into serotonin in the body, and that serotonin is responsible for elevated brain activity. It's known commonly as a mediating substance for happiness and well-being. 

Is a bag containing flour, eggs, baking powder, and water a cake? No, it's not only the constituents of a system that give it its identity and function, it is also how particular arrangements of the dead things interact to try to achieve equilibrium.

"The Selfish Gene" was an extremely instructive book for explaining what evolution is. That, at least, is a definable and answerable question. If we want to find out what life is, we're probably going to have to start from something more empirical like this.

Evolution is quite simply a process that optimizes information based on that information's ability to replicate itself. Obviously any information which doesn't self-replicate fails this test right away. However, you can still generalize the concept to weird extremes because different kinds of information work together to promote mutual survival and replication on a larger scale. Consider lipid cell walls. This isn't DNA, it's just a physical form, but it also has a function, and the degree to which it fulfills this function affects the prevalence of that form in future generations. Dawkins solves this by using weird tricks with the definitions we employ.

At the start of the video the narrator forms an analogy from Schroedinger's definition of life. The narrator says that your downloads folder is like dead things, just matter in a big chaotic jumble. But if you expend ENERGY you can bring order to those files in the folder. So the narrator starts off by describing LIFE as ENERGY, at lease according to an eminent quantum physicist.

Later in the video he describes how older scientific theories believed that you could not create the stuff that makes up living things (organic matter) from non-living things (inorganic matter). The scientific theories he is talking about are known as "Vitalism" and that portion of finalist theory was discredited (when Urea was synthesized in a lab).

But here is the interesting bit. Deciding that Vitalism (or any theory that characterizes life as energy or other force) should be discredited just because one of its theories was incorrect is throwing the cells out with the primordial soup. Biological science decided that there was only one way to look at the problem of life: by starting at the smallest parts (classical physics and chemistry) and building up to the biggest parts (living things). But maybe there is another way.

Physicists are not troubled by the existence of two radically different ways of describing our universe. The existence of quantum physics does not disprove classical physics. Why can't life be a type of energy worthy of study?

Now I am not saying we go back to Vitalism or some sort of New Age theories, but isn't it worth exploring the possibility that life is it's own thing that we should strive to understand, perhaps with a very different approach than reductionist biology?

For more on these ideas, check out this book by Alexis Mari Peitak called "Life as Energy". http://www.amazon.com/Life-As-Energy-Opening-Science/dp/0863157971

She is a biophysicist that asks some intriguing questions about our current understanding of biology and life.

When broken down into these simple terms, it's easy to understand. Except, existence is not that simple. It's more than a technical definition of "alive" and "dead". It's the difference between metaphysics, and physics. One of the flaws in trying to define "life" through physics, is that it can't account for what we don't know. Superstring Theory suggests the universe exists in 10 dimensions. Each higher dimension essentially being like a parallel or alternate universe, with the 10th dimension being an entirely different form of reality we can't conceive of. These higher dimensions could be influencing our own in ways we have only been able to describe as supernatural, or paranormal.

Like "alien UFO's", which are actually not extraterrestrial, but from another dimension (universe). The same for so called "Men in Black". Both behave in ways that are against the laws of physics. Such as M.I.B. making things fade out of existence, or making themselves disappear. UFO's are known to move at impossible speeds that would crush anyone inside. Some move so fast that they seem to simply disappear in an instant.

Just throwing my opinion in: we just discussed all most the same thing in philosophy: at the end we came to the conclusion  that names (words) are not bound to specific thing and I could call my computer a fish and it would still be right. What I mean by that is  that you don't need to define "life" and say that life is something what eats and reproduces itself and then get into trouble when looking at bacteria. You can just say "those animals and plants are alive and this rock isn't and you don't need exact definitions why it is alive.

God is a placebo. People look at the universe from a perplexed (and somewhat ignorant) standpoint, and are therefore more and more inclined to seeing God in that which they cannot understand. They take comfort in "knowing" that there is a creator, and that it is actually concerned with humanity, sin, and other petty things. The truth is, the universe couldn't care less about what humans think of it or themselves. Intelligent self-aware life has been around for a miniscule fraction of the universe's time span, and it is the result of natural processes that take place regardless of whether or not people believe in them. Some may say that believing in a creator is a sign of open-mindedness, but it's really just people expecting others to be just as confused and amazed about life as they are.

Don't get me wrong here, I too am perplexed at life, and often ponder on my own existence. I personally think a more relevant question to ask, especially in the realm of ethics, is what "feels". We know ourselves capable of feeling, and there is enough evidence that other people, and other life forms have a similar setup, so I think it's reasonable to assume they feel. The source of this feeling is important, but even before/if that's found, it's important to recognize that it's there. After we recognize that, it's simple mathematics. Suffering is demonstrably bad, therefore you shouldn't inflict any on anyone unless it will result in a higher gain in positive experience. If the goal isn't happiness, then what is it? If there isn't a goal, then what is there to lose for trying?

Since most things I can think of are made of the dead material of stars, most things are dead, but are probably part of the life of another system. That said I think that sapience or sentience is not required for life. Is a germ any more aware of our efforts to effect them than a star is of how hot it makes us? A factory assembly line is alive despite being built by us, just as we are alive but cannot create other humans without using biology. Cities are alive, countries. rock bands. I would go as far as to say that how alive something is does have degrees. A loose collection of photons flying around the universe is very low on the life metric, whereas an amalgamation of photons in a laser ranks higher, and the photons that play a part in the system of photosynthesis rank yet higher. Of course this system is observer dependent so, yeah

Loved the video! But of course it's an irrelevant question. We're DNA adapting itself in order to continue its existence, the only reason we even have a concept of "self" is because at some point in our evolution our molecular structure tried it out in one offspring and, well, it worked. It probably resulted in self-preservation, which helped us survive. But what are "we"? Our body? Cool, we don't even have conscious control of it all, and "our" body has about ten times more autonomous microorganisms in it (i.e. gut flora) than actual human cells. Yet, we think of our bodies as ours merely because our neural synapses can "consciously" move some limbs and muscles.  We're just part of the ecossystem as much as cells are part of tissues, which are part of organs. It doesn't "stop" with us, we're the only ones drawing this line, our ego and self-awareness are just resources.
And that's in no way a bad thing, or "cold", or whatever. It's amazing. We're the universe trying to understand itself, we exist to pass along information, we don't need to go looking for meaning, because, as far as we know, we're the only ones who developed the ability to make one. So... let's make it.

We created the meaning of the word "life" a long time ago, based on "this thing we have". It's not a fact of the universe, the reason the line becomes blurry with the more we learn is because the very word is obsolete. "Alive" and "dead" are just the best definitions we've got for the duration of time in which our DNA puts everything together, so we just have to roll with it for now.

Or at least that's how I see it, that might be complete bullshit.

This is like asking the question "Do computers know how to do math?" Bcoz computers are made of stuff that doesn't know how to do math, but reacts with each other in a way that looks like it's doing math.

No magic, the human brain is a remarkable machine with a super efficient processor and data storage technology hundreds of millions of years in the making. It creates it's own operating system of beliefs and boundaries and then runs constant accuracy tests to improve upon it. It assigns qualitative values like "alive" and "dead" to shorthand the world around it for it's own processing efficiency, and then checks it's definitions. Through a series of complex physical and chemical reactions, it has developed a network connecting it to other humans, and cross references it's own data with that of those other operating systems for the sake of maximizing group accuracy and efficiency. Another interesting thing that challenges the notion of what it means to be alive are prions, the pathogens behind Varient Creuzfeldt-Jakobs Disease and Mad Cow Disease.  These diseases are caused by mis-folded proteins transmit their misfolded state onto other protiens causing them to become prions.  In a sense it can be considered reproduction, or atleast replication. However, prions only are made of protien and lack nucleic acids, that all other living organisms have including viruses. It is something interesting to consider.

Consciousness—Philosophers have used the term 'consciousness' for four main topics: knowledge in general, intentionality, introspection (and the knowledge it specifically generates) and phenomenal experience... Something within one's mind is 'introspectively conscious' just in case one introspects it (or is poised to do so). Introspection is often thought to deliver one's primary knowledge of one's mental life. An experience or other mental entity is 'phenomenally conscious' just in case there is 'something it is like' for one to have it. The clearest examples are: perceptual experience, such as tastings and seeings; bodily-sensational experiences, such as those of pains, tickles and itches; imaginative experiences, such as those of one's own actions or perceptions; and streams of thought, as in the experience of thinking 'in words' or 'in images'. Introspection and phenomenality seem independent, or dissociable, although this is controversial.

Dear @*****  ,
as always an awesome video!
But i think you might have some possibly "faulty" premisses in your argumentation. (or simplify the situation too much by leaving out some factors)
Actually we can't answer these questions yet from what we know because:

Firstly: The concept of Emergence. (the whole is more than the sum of its parts), The apparent phenomenon that "complex systems" ("real complexity") gain propertys, and the existence of consciousness might be a "Emerging" effect, and if this is a physical property of the universe your whole argumentation is lackluster, we just don't know this yet, as we know so little about emergence. (huge complex topic can'tgo too deep ofc :) )

Secondly: As far as we know, Consciousness could be a physical property and if complex living organisms act like an antenna to acess or somehow "produce" this "consciousness" there would also be a a "factual" difference between life and death.

Thirdly: The still unknown macro level or quantum physics, some theorists suggest that the mind might be the result of complex quantum effects interacting which. (strong claim, but we can't answer this yet.)

Your video looks at the world from a deterministic, materialistic perspective, which might seem to be the only "scientific perspective" but it is actually not the only logical/philosophical explanation. We just know too little to answer these questions with as strong statements as you did. If you want to provoke thats fine ofc, but i don't think all viewers know about the more complex ongoing philosophical and scientifical debate about this.

Still, thanks a lot for the video, and keep it up! :).

[ 4:08 - 4:38 ] I hate to say this, Kurzgesagt, but you never actually prove (i)that living things DO NOT "contain some non-physical element" that distinguishes them from non-living things. In fact, at the start of your video, you seem to suggest that we don't know what 'life is' and therefore cannot give any definitive answer as to its (possible) physical properties while you do a very good job of showing how ambiguous the whole process is. Yet, by conflating or quickly lumping this unproven premise together with the much more easily proven premise: (ii)that living things ARE NOT "governed by different principles than inanimate objects" which is the basis of most scientific discovery, gives a false equitability between the empirically observable, physical aspects of the world and a METAphysical implication like the one you mistakenly make in your first premise(i).  
This is not to say that you are "wrong" in the opinion that there is no metaphysical aspect to life. Since something like that, by nature, is not empirically observable it is fair to say that there is no way of proving that is exists EMPIRICALLY. However, this is why this premise (i) is an opinion, and should not be passed off as some definitive statement about 'life'. You cannot prove or disprove the existence of something metaphysical, physically/empirically, but you can prove that all physical objects/substances that we know of operate under the same physical rules. 
As for the idea that something non-physical is, therefore, "magical" is just silly. Dial it back, and lets keep the conversation scientific, rather than over reaching your boundaries into the philosophical/theological. Again, this is not to say that you are wrong in your opinion, but you are not doing a good job here of showing that premise (i) is not something scientifically provable, and instead you are doing all you can to make it seem like this is a definitive fact, which it is not.
All that being said, I really enjoy your videos, which is why I felt the need to make this criticism, and I will continue to enjoy them! Thanks very much!

Just because everything is made out of the same stuff doesn't mean that we can't make classifications such as the ones between life and death. We're made out of the same materials that people a thousand years ago were made out of, but that doesn't mean we're the same people. I know that's not the best analogy, but still.

There aren't many real binary classifications like life/death. Things happen in a gradient. It's hard to draw the line because everybody is using different definitions. You can still observe things and analyse them without a clear classification. I think people probably spend too much time arguing over how to classify things and lose focus of how amazing everything is.

Here's my 2 euros (I think my ideas are worth more than 2 cents).

I remember Noam Chomsky saying that continuity is a human way of viewing the universe. We are the ones who care about drawing the boundaries as to when is a baby born and when does it die (google Theseus ship).
But nature works in a more chaotic way. It's an endless motion and information like when does life begin/end are completely useless for it. Nature needs nothing more than constant change. We are the weirdos actually, because we ask such questions. The rest of the universe is pretty okay with the constant change.

I think it all boils down to emergence. A water molecule is not responsible for the tides...and, at the same time, it is. See, this molecule gains the liquid property only when in a place with other water molecules, forming a tide.
Just like a country is not a single entity, but made up of the peoples' lives and decisions, our consciousness is made of tiny bits of neurons that eventually build the mind.

You just have to zoom out/in in order to change your perspective. Any approach is correct, as long as you keep in mind that there are other levels at which an atom, a neuron and a human operate.
Without the mind as a whole, the neurons would not be part of the same web.
And without the neurons, there would be no mind.

There's a point where "a bunch of bricks" becomes a house. It is no longer just a bunch of bricks, because as a house, it has gained new properties.
We will defy entropy and achieve immortality, I'm sure of it.

...but it did find this article if it strikes anyone's fancy. It talks about how bacteria colonies use cell death in a way that multicellular organisms do:

http://discovermagazine.com/1995/sep/deathandthemicro557

Life is reproduction, consumption, and addiction. Life is a DNA molecular with its only one goal of reproducing itself. Living things are subjects of their appetites ...food and sex, needs and wants. Biology itself tricks us into being addicted to this life thing. We want and need things without ever really thinking about why we want and need things. I would argue that life places us in a constant motion of need and suffering. That's why as living things we are always searching for that which will fill us, make us happy, and stop the pain (physically, emotionally, or mentally). But once we are full, we always get hungry again. No one can stay happy and satisfied with life all the time. And as living things we age and eventually life slips away from all of us anyways. We confront ourselves and our psychologies by telling ourselves cozy fairytales of "mother nature" and of a "heavenly father" and tales of an afterlife. But the reality is that we had no choice in being born and we have no choice in not dying. With this life thing we sure do find ourselves in a peculiar fix.
To me, the question of life and death is meaningless, yet interesting - at least it's interesting to read, watch and listen to peoples ideas about it (even though some are just stupid to me...).

I shall now define life: Life is a conscious being, like humans, primates, horses, dogs, fish and other life forms that actively seek for reproduction, genetic continuation and energy, instead of just laying around waiting until they can chemically capture some molecule. In this classification, non-life forms are classified as "simple non-life form", "complex non-life form" and "semi-life forms". Simple non-life forms are molecules like hydrogen, water, and so on.  Complex non-life forms are viruses and simple bacteria and algae that lay around pretty much like molecules just waiting to interact with the environment and semi-life forms are complex beings that do not entirely match the definition of life and arguably aren't conscious. For now on life is being conscious that you're alive and death is never being conscious of anything again.

Here is something to think about.

I want you to think about the concept of absolute nothing. No concept of black, white, up, down, time, space, matter or a vacuum. Complete and utter nothing. Difficult to think about isn't it? Now lets make things weird!

Just to blow your mind a little bit, you also have to consider that this concept of absolute nothing also does not have a concept of physics, rules, laws or constraints.

So if you had a bubble of absolute nothing right now, what is stopping this bubble from becoming something, anything and everything all within one instantaneous point as well as the vastness of infinity all at the same time? It has no rules or laws remember.

Now this is where things get very weird when you consider the concept of absolute everything. If you ever did have a bubble of absolute everything, then surely this would also contain absolute nothing, otherwise it would not be "everything" it would be "everything except nothing".

This now leaves us with the scenario where nothing can become everything, and everything must contain nothing...
